title: Finally messaged a therapist
body:
Er well I messaged 2 but I think that's better?

My financial situation has kinda been in flux for the past month and I didn't think I would be able to afford it. But now I'm making it a priority. 

I'm weirdly proud of myself but disappointed it's taken this long for me to take this step. Especially after encouraging others to do that same. I'm such a hypocrite but hey, I'm trying :)

title: Should I give my pronouns (they/them) at my job interview?
body: I am graduating from university next week (yay!) and I have my first real job interview tomorrow. Its one I'm pretty excited about, so I really want to do this right. On top of all my other worries about answering their questions right, I am not sure if I should basically come out at my interview. On one hand, I know I am assumed binary, and if I get hired, I don't want to start off with that misunderstanding. On the other hand, I worry that it being the first (or one of the first) things the interviewer learns about me, she might get put off by that. I know it's awful that that's even a consideration, but I think we all know it's a possibility. I trust that this company wouldn't intentionally discriminate (their website mentions their support of diversity etc) but I just have to think if I'm equivalent to another candidate but they're binary.... I'd be the less attractive option

title: Question about genitalia on estrogen
body:
So I'm a "cis male" currently contemplating hrt, but I have one concern I would like to keep my penis working if possible, and I've heard from some people that as long as you keep using it, it will keep functioning but I've also heard from some other people that if you're on hrt for a long enough period of time (like say 5 years or more) it will stop working and be nearly impossible to get erections. 

So my question is, Is this true? 

And is there any way to prevent that from happening?

title: Why do people say being Non Binary is fake?
body:
I've always been confused as to why certain figures outside of the lgbtq plus community and inside believe that the concept of Non Binary is fake. 
I first began identifying as Non binary in 2019 due to me having an incongruence between my internal perception and male gendered stereotypes. I feel like some people say that then I could just be a Non gender conforming male, but that means I'm still putting myself into that box in a way. I do not think I've ever had what is medically referred to as gender dsyphoria but is who I am as an enby person invalid because I never have but have no desire to go back to the typical male pronouns either..
It feels like many people believe that it is and I am always feeling ashamed constantly about it.

title: How do you explain how not identifying with your AGAB is different than disliking gender stereotypes?
body: Most of my friends tell me "you can be a girl and not be girly- those are just stereotypes..." etc. And while disliking being boxed in by stereotypes is the cause of most of my dysphoria, it's more than that: i just don't particularly relate to being a man or a woman. I know i can be non-binary without persuading my friends, but is there a better way to explain it? They're all cisgendered and don't understand.

title: Non-Binary Media
body: Lately I've been wanting to find more trans and more specifically non-binary media. If you have any shows, movies, books (fiction and non-ficiton) with non-binary main character(s) that you would recommended let me know :)

title: I lost a friend yesterday because he was posting that biological sex is essential, and now I‚Äôm feeling very confused and alone
body:
First time posting here but I‚Äôve just been really struggling with this. I‚Äôm an AMAB nb, I came out to most of my friends about a year ago. My friend from high school, who has been my best friend for a long time, was posting in defense of JK Rowling and basically mimicking her views on biological sex etc. This isn‚Äôt the first time he‚Äôs expressed this, he knows I‚Äôm nb, and basically just won‚Äôt accept that it‚Äôs transphobic because he ‚Äúhold[s] no hate in his heart for trans people, but think[s] gender identity and physical sex are different.‚Äù I told him he was being stubborn and ignorant and he said that he isn‚Äôt sure he can be friends with someone who sees him that way. 

It just sucks really bad. He and I play games together constantly and it‚Äôs long been my main source of relaxation, and we‚Äôve been friends for 10 years. He made me feel like it‚Äôs my fault for being so ideological or rigid, but I‚Äôm really hurt by all his bullshit. I don‚Äôt know if I‚Äôm asking for advice or sympathy, but I‚Äôm so depressed I just don‚Äôt know what to do or how to feel. Sorry for the long post or if I used the wrong tag

title: How long should the "Grace period" last?
body:
At what point should the grace period for getting my name and pronouns right end? It's been two years with my pronouns now, and I still get called the wrong ones. üòí My name I can understand since it's been less than six months. The pronouns are harder to justify.

I don't think they're being inconsiderate *intentionally*. They just haven't put in the practice to readjust their thinking, and I have a hard time correcting them because of my anxiety. üòî I'm just so tired of my friends and family not trying.

title: i feel like i shouldn't be genderless so i've been trying to convince myself to be a binary gender
body:
for the first fifteen years of my life, i assumed i was a girl, since that's what i was called. but then i realized that i didn't really feel like one or want to be one, and then nonbinary fit me better. i don't feel like i have a gender. i don't feel like i'm a girl. i don't feel like i'm a boy

but that's not normal. no matter how many more people accept it now than a few decades ago, it's still an unusual thing that others me and inconveniences people. that's been bothering me a lot lately

i've been trying to convince myself that i'm a boy. i think things like "well i like how the word 'boy' looks and sounds so maybe i wouldn't mind being called it. and i can whisper the phrase 'i'm a boy' to myself without feeling horrible. so maybe it's true. maybe i'm actually a boy."

but even typing that makes me anxious. i don't want to be boy. i don't want to be a man. i've tried calling myself those things in private and it doesn't make me happy. however, my stupid ocd brain keeps going "oh no, that's not anxiety, that's happiness. it means you have to be a boy now." but i know what happiness feels like. it's how i feel when my dad calls me "they" even when he thinks i can't hear him. it's when i see nonbinary characters in media i enjoy. the feeling isn't the same as that one. it's an anxious feeling

so then my brain goes "well maybe you're just being in denial cause men can be bad". but that's not true. my dad is a man and he's a great person. if i were a man, i would be too. but even typing "if i were a man" makes me anxious and uncomfortable, so i know i'm not. but the pressure won't stop. i feel like i have to settle for that

They didn‚Äôt quite get it and I don‚Äôt completely either, I know you exist and are valid I just don‚Äôt quite understand. Was hoping some of you great people could help educate me and my friends!

title: Do you think that being nonbinary helps to deconstruct the social construct of gender?
body: I am writing an essay for university and I wanted to write about something that I have been thinking of for years now. I am nonbinary, which means for me that I dislike that the category "gender" exists at all. But nonbinary is just another category imo and I am a bit worried that having this "third" category just reinforces the genderstereotypes of what it means to be "male" or "female". What do you think? Does it help to have more and more people coming out as nonbinary to loosen up gender roles? What is your perspective on that topic?

title: Top surgery without serious dysphoria?
body:
Hi y‚Äôall, so I‚Äôm 28, afab, non-binary, and have begun using they/them pronouns, all the basics that I find are fitting to my gender experience. I‚Äôve been thinking about top surgery for years, for a couple reasons. I don‚Äôt like wearing bras, binders, any kind of band or pressure to my chest. It makes me feel claustrophobic in my own body. I‚Äôd rather just go braless. But with that‚Ä¶stuff doesn‚Äôt fit right, they bounce (lol), and I just don‚Äôt love the lack of freedom that comes with having tiddies (I live in the US). It also has to do with my gender identity, and wanting to distance myself from ‚Äòwoman.‚Äô But I don‚Äôt consider myself to have serious chest dysphoria. If I was never able to get top surgery I‚Äôd be bummed, but I‚Äôd be able to live my life. 

More and more tho I really WANT top surgery. But I don‚Äôt know that many people who got it without having some significant amount of dysphoria. Has anyone here gotten top surgery who didn‚Äôt have specific chest dysphoria? 

Thanks for responding! üíú

title: Were you ever unsure of being an enby, and if so, what made you know for sure? I'm questioning right now
body:
So, for about a year now I've considered myself a binary trans woman, and it's been pretty good. More recently though I realised I much prefer she/they to she/her, and I like being able to pull out my masc voice if/when I feel like it. I actually really want to make a DND character that changes between having stereotypically male and female forms, just so I can use both voices

Edit: After thinking about it I've come to the conclusion I'm a binary woman. I like having a male voice, but it's never something I'd use in regular conversation, it's a novelty, it isn't *my* voice

title: Am I non-binary?
body:
I'm 28, assigned female at birth, and never had a problem with that. I was raised in a very religious town, and I had barely heard the word "gay" before high school. I'd certainly never heard of trans, non-binary, or any other gender identity. Then my best friend came out as trans when we were in our early twenties, and I started reading up on it. I brought up to my boyfriend (now fianc√©) that I thought I might be agender. He essentially laughed and said "no, you're not".

I put it away. I was happy with my body. I was happy presenting as female, though tomboy-ish. I still am. But lately, I've been feeling extremely uncomfortable with the word "woman". I don't know how to explain it, other than that it feels wrong. It doesn't feel like me. But female pronouns feel okay, which just makes me more confused.

I'm looking for some insight, I guess. How did you know you were non-binary? What does it feel like for you? Does my experience make sense?

She said it would look better like that üôÑ I asked her to fix it but she said no because I would look like a boy then....

For people who will ask why I posted it here. I'm working on my nonbinary look right now and I wanted to start with the hair...

title: Have you been told by your parents that you are "abusive" or "insulting them" by changing your name/pronouns?
body: Kind of a rant, I'm afab and go by he/him and a different name than my birth name. I HATE my birth name and I have expressed this to my parents, at first in the softest way possible. I have been kind and forgiving about coming out, but my family has stated that they flat out refuse to use my name and pronouns. They have called me "mentally ill", blamed my age for "making me want to cope with trauma by changing my name". They basically think it's a coping strategy, something the internet has convinced me to do, etc. It is so hurtful and annoying and honestly I don't even want to see them anymore. They deadname me and use the wrong pronouns. When I came out, my father told me I would have to "choose between my bullshit name" or essentially "reject my mother and abandon the relationship completely". Basically they gave me two choices: continue to use my deadname, or reject my family and use my new name. I was accused of being abusive and selfish for "rejecting the name they spent so much time choosing". They accused me of rejecting my family as well. It just honestly sucks. I feel like a jerk for continuing to use my preferred name, they've even told me that if they hear others referring to me as my preferred name, they will take all of my belongings away. Am I a jerk for insisting that others use my pronouns? Should I be more forgiving to my parents?

title: Should I stop talking HRT? I think I'm having body dysphoria from my developing breasts.
body: I am non-binary, AMAB, and I started taking spiro and estradiol under two months ago. The boob part was the one component that I was worried about. I just didn't know how it would feel. Things have been changing faster and faster. And it's not like I'm 100% that I will feel weird about them. This could be just a temporary adjustment phase. But I'm seriously considering stopping the HRT, because as you probably know, the growth isn't reversible. I feel stupid, and like a fake, and like the trans and non-binary community is going to judge the crap out of me. Any advice or stories of similar issues would be very much appreciated.

title: Me 24 months ago: So yeah, I'm non-binary. Surprise! Would be really cool if you all could use they/them pronouns. Everyone Else: hey bro, man, dude, brother, son, sir, squire, big man, gent, etc...
body:

I get that it's hard but if I can do it, so can you. It just takes practice and compassion. 

Is this the norm or have I just surrounded myself with selfish people?

title: Anyone else struggle with Christmas?
body:
I‚Äôm heading home for Christmas tomorrow and I have such complex feelings. I miss my family, but differing views, family drama and changes in our lives make it really tough now.
Gender played such a huge role in my childhood family dynamic, like a stereotypical nuclear family. Now I don‚Äôt fit in with that anymore, and the whole holiday feels different, the nostalgia and feelings feel overwhelming. Family life was easier when I just bent myself out of shape and went along with the family, but now I am my own person, it‚Äôs lonely. 
Not religious at all, just feel like the world is a different place from when I was a child. Because I see the world and myself differently, and while I‚Äôm happier in myself, a lot of waking up to the realities of the world has changed my perception. Hard to feel Christmassy with so much sadness and pain out there. 

Does anyone else share this feeling?

title: People around me think I‚Äôm non-binary and I don‚Äôt really know what to think
body:
So I‚Äôve been thinking about gender for awhile and experimented with gender expression stuff like getting a male haircut and wearing a binder. (I‚Äôve already been wearing male clothes) and I look pretty androgynous. I‚Äôm afab.
So now, here‚Äôs the thing. It started with my cousin, who‚Äôs super awesome and the best cousin ever. He was talking to me about sweet 16 and how it was a real big party for teenage girls in particular, but then said something along the lines of ‚Äúbut it could be for whatever you identify with‚Äù hmm
Next I went to his house because he and my other cousin, his sister, had some hand me downs. First he got some of his clothes and a couple of his sisters clothes, but before getting her clothes he said to me, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know how feminine you want to go but you might like some of these.‚Äù Hmmm
Now the third thing (sorry if y‚Äôall are getting bored with this) was when I was messing around with my little brothers friends (nine year old boys) at the park. Casually this one kid said something like ‚Äú(name) isn‚Äôt really a girl and (name) isn‚Äôt really a boy. (name) is just (name)‚Äù he didn‚Äôt say this to be mean at all, just kind of in a serious but jokey manner. HMMM.
I‚Äôm putting this here because I kind of want to know what you all think. Thanks for taking the time to read üëå

title: Question for non-binary Metroid fans
body:
So I'm a big Metroid fan, I'm also a non-binary person who tends to present similar to their AGAB

As someone who plays a lot of Metroid, I kind of identify with Samus in a lot of ways. We all know Samus looks like a woman, but they (going to use natural pronouns) definitely do not act like one

Samus is generally thought to be a pretty stoic character, in the one game where they were depicted as behaving very feminine, the community threw a fit because it wasn't how anyone thought Samus would act, in other games, such as Fusion, Samus was very stoic and to the point, which is typically seen as a masculine trait

It's certainly not up to me to decide Samus's gender, but they definitely don't seem like an overly feminine woman, and as a non-binary person who was AMAB, but doesn't act particularly masculine, I find this sort of representative of my own experience. Has anyone else ever thought this? If not about Samus, about other game characters? I'm curious to hear everyone's thoughts

I didn't get any actual studies, nor did I really go into their sources but it just exhausted me to be on these websites due to the degrading insults... No site really referred to any studies in the text as far as I read at least
And I was just wondering
Is there any research into xenogender and where could I find them?

title: Would it be rude to wear a bandaid on my shot site to pride?
body:
I know not all non-binary individuals are on Hrt but I am. I'm actually really proud and happy about it since it's harder to tell my gender now.

I take my Hrt tomorrow night and usually leave it on for a day or two regardless. So for pride I was thinking about getting a really obnoxious bandaid to cover my shot location this year. Meaning I would actually be mostly for decoration/ demonstration.  

Maybe even write pronouns on it if I feel so bold.

I have a friend, Trans femme, who told me that I shouldn't because it would be rude to Trans/ non-binary people who aren't on hrt. She said that I would be making other cis people think that non-binarys need to be on Hrt.

I think she just generally dislikes me being enby and on hrt at this point since it's not the only time she's been critical of me on Hrt or not confirming. 

Only reason I'm asking is cause I am kinda concerned, she's claiming that she knows better as an elder Trans and has the backing of some of our Trans group.

So would it really be rude to do it?

Edit: Just updating
Wore the bandaid and had no issues. Pride was great and I had fun. The one friend didn't even come to pride, she posted in group chat that she felt like it was a waste of time.

title: How did y‚Äôall know you weren‚Äôt cis?
body: I constantly find myself going back and forth and trying to understand my feelings. As an AMAB, and being brought up in a sometimes traumatic household, all I ever did was repress my feelings and not think about them. I get bottom dysphoria more than anything else rn, and there are a few other things like my Adam‚Äôs Apple and some facial features and UGH ALL THE BODY HAIR but other than that I just feel invalid. Not to mention I‚Äôm not even sure if that would be enough to a therapist to constitute HRT and a transition of some sort. I‚Äôve had these feelings and have been considering them to the best of my ability for the past 2.5-3 years which isn‚Äôt easy with my constant repression of feelings. I just want to live a happy life and whether trans or not, i want these feelings to go away :(

title: Dysphoria getting worse after egg cracks?
body: I tried my first binder recently and I was mostly curious how it would feel but I ended up literally crying from the euphoria I felt when I was wearing it.  I looked in the mirror and it was like I was finally the person I was supposed to be.  I had never felt that way before and it was incredible!  But now I'm finding myself feeling dysphoric in very cute dresses that made me feel really good just a month ago.  I'm wondering if my gender changed or if my egg cracked and this is how I'm going to be now.  I still like feminine stuff like makeup and painted nails, but for some reason if I come across as very girly and cis (I am AFAB) I feel pretty bad since I started wearing my binder.  I also feel more dysphoria around my chest now and HATE seeing my boobs bounce when I walk or when I look down. Is this kind of change something that just happens when your egg cracks?  I think only time will tell but I'd be really curious what y'alls thoughts are.

title: Came out to my liberal in-laws and they were less accepting then my openly conservative family
body: My in laws not only told me that they don‚Äôt want to discuss this ‚Äúpersonal matter‚Äù anymore but they also decided that it was a good opportunity to tell me after 10 years of knowing then that they would like me to now call them by their last names ‚Äúmr and mrs ‚Äú !!!!  I have been calling them by their first name for the last 10 years and they now want to change that. Not only did they make my coming out about them but they acted offended that I was upset by this. I‚Äôm really hurt but on a positive note my spouse stuck up for me and we both agree and told them we will not longer be visiting them this year like we planned and we won‚Äôt even speak to them until they apologize. Ugh!!! Life so strange sometimes I know my conservative family doesn‚Äôt agree with the GOP but there still conservatives so I thought coming out to them was going to be hard but it was actually sooo easy compared to my liberal in-laws who talk down on my family for being conservative they think there close minded but turns out they were projecting this whole time. üôÉ

title: sometimes i wish ppl would stop seeing boobs and immediately think "WOMAN!"
body:
Like ok i know that so unrealistic and maybe it shouldn't be a problem because it is typical for women to have boobs, but damn can it be so invalidating sometimes. 

even when i was super young, like 5th-6th grade people would comment on my chest size. Like the fact it was small was my biggest problem. People would say, "it's ok, just give them time to grow" as if my validity of being a woman rided on the fact that i had big boobs, or that i should feel sad in some way that they weren't bigger. It felt so weird and honestly grossed me out because i never wanted boobs, i was content with my chest size and lowkey hoped it would never grow. 

And so for the longest time i wrestled with the idea of being a fake woman and not as attractive because my chest was small, because thats the pressure that society put me under before i even went through puberty. It got so bad that men would take my chest size as an opportunity to say anything at all. Like because they are smaller than average its ok for them to continuously comment on them, sexualize them, or hate on them. 

i really hate it, i wish woman wouldn't immediately be put down for their small chests.

i wish people would stop commenting on my chest. 

and i wish having boobs at all wouldn't make ppl think im a girl. It's so hard to deal with..

title: I told my boss my pronouns, she failed to use them. I introduced myself to my new work team with my pronouns, none of them used them.
body:
Pretty much what it says on the tin. I started a new job and during the hiring process I mentioned I preferred to go by they/them. My new supervisor then introduced me with female pronouns to most of my co-workers. I wasn't mad I just figured maybe she didn't fully understand.

On my first official day we had a team meeting and I introduced myself as non-binary and my preferred pronouns. One of them polietly asked what that meant and I simply explained I'd like them to replace she and her with they and them. The few coworkers I worked with that day only referred to me as she/her.

I took a lot of courage and a lot of anxiety to tell my boss and my group, and I don't have the mental energy to keep reminding them. My friend who also works in this company said HR has pronoun pins but I don't even know where to go to get them or if my location has them.

title: ‚ÄúThis is lesbian night tonight by the way. Just so you know.‚Äù
body:
This is more of a rant and a ramble, but a bouncer at a gay club said this to me last night and it felt like a gut punch. 

Yeah, I know it is. I was just in here for the past hour with my friends, and had finally just started to feel okay and like I belonged. I‚Äôm non-binary (agender but fine with any pronouns) but I like presenting masc and generally lean pretty heavy in that direction. Nonetheless, my other queer friends and I were out and they wanted to go to this one bar, and I figured I‚Äôd be okay if I stuck with them.  

But my friends stepped out for a smoke and I followed them out. I got cold and so I went back in early. The bouncer (who hadn‚Äôt asked anything of anyone in our group coming in) chased me down to check my ID and inform me what night it was. 

I get it. I present way more masc than anyone else in my group. I have a beard. But I also (hope? thought?) read as pretty queer, but I don‚Äôt know if that should even matter. 

I walked away but it left me feeling so self-conscious and othered I ended up just going to the bathroom and texting my friends I was leaving. 

As I was leaving, I quietly mentioned to the bouncer that I felt not great about the comment, and they said ‚ÄúI have to watch out for these girls. So whenever someone who looks masc comes through I make sure to tell them to be respectful. It‚Äôs not like I said you weren‚Äôt welcome here.‚Äù  

You didn‚Äôt have to say it. 

Anyways, I‚Äôve just found myself ruminating on this whole interaction, and it‚Äôs brought up all sorts of old feelings about being an imposter in queer spaces. This was my first time going to a night like this, and I wouldn‚Äôt have ever been brave enough to go without my friends‚Äô encouragement, but it feels like that vulnerability was met with a punch in the face. 

I don‚Äôt have anywhere I‚Äôm going with this, I guess I‚Äôm just feeling pretty fake.

title: Working as a non binary person (Rant)
body:
Sorry this might be a little long of a rant 

So I came out as non binary at my workplace recently, which was a very difficult thing for me to do. I asked to be called a different name(let‚Äôs call it X), for a pronoun pin, and for management to enforce the name change. Half of the people I work with didn‚Äôt care and just call me X and will correct themselves if they call me my dead name. Sounds good right? Well the other half has been weird with it. 

The others keep calling me my dead name and get sorta frustrated at me when I correct them. They‚Äôll often say ‚Äúwell that‚Äôs not respectful for me to call you X‚Äù or they‚Äôll ignore it. They‚Äôre older of course, all of them are in their 50s+. I didn‚Äôt expect it to go smoothly with them at first but it‚Äôs been two weeks of constant correcting and I‚Äôm tired of it. I know most of them are trying but his just annoying sometimes. And I feel bad for being annoyed at them. 

The company also requires us to only wear company approved pins on our lanyard, so when I came out I asked if I could get an approved one. The request is now with the company‚Äôs legal team because ‚Äúit could open up the idea for other political pins.‚Äù Dude, why is the way I want people to address me ‚Äúpolitical‚Äù but one of my managers wearing a ‚Äúlet‚Äôs go Brandon‚Äù bracelet isn‚Äôt?! It actually frustrates me beyond belief that they can wear that bracelet but my pin would cross the line. Now to be fair, upper management probably doesn‚Äôt know about the bracelet, but it‚Äôs still frustrating nonetheless. 

Overall I‚Äôm both happy and upset that I came out at work. But if I‚Äôm gonna be honest I kinda hope I get a better job offer soon that way I can leave and find a more comfortable environment.

title: Just wanna like... switch the body I have on each day until I'm in the skin that makes me, me.
body:
I have the typical male frame that gym bros and a few guys I've met want. The six foot three, broad shouldered, masculine stereotype. But I hate it. I can't change or control the size or shape of it and I want something different. And because I hate it, I keep beating it up with things I can control, mainly food, used to be drugs too but use quit all of that now. 

I just want to have a mirror or a wardrobe where I walk up and whatever body I want to have can be chosen and swapped. 

For years I have joked with friends that I am a lesbian in a man's body. Most of the time I was met with similar jokes and basically always brushed off as a guy that really likes to go down town. 

But this past year, my two closest friends have really listened to me and helped me see the light that I am gender fluid and most of the time I am genuinely a woman that like women. I only two reasons I don't wear skirts is because of the stigma in my own head and that I know a massive bloke looking person with a belly doesn't look that great in a skirt. 

I want to be at least a foot shorter, half my damn breadth and cute as a button. I used to have a best friend that I could really see myself as. I would have sold my soul to be her. But that made me toxic to her and everyone around us because I didn't understand anything around what was happening to me. 

I just want the world to see me as the cute little person I know I am and not this hulking beast I've been downloaded into. 

But. I have been so much happier and confident since the realisation that I am gender fluid or probably trans. I've not settled on a qualifier yet as I am still evolving as a person. Just hate the skin I'm in. If there's ever a way, let's find a ftm person that wants this one and I'll gladly trade :)

title: r/detrans completely freaked me out
body:
Someone asked, "how do you know you're not trans?" and a comment straight up said, "trans isn't real, hormone addiction and mental illness is". Yikes, I can't unsee this shit.

I don't believe it but wtf, why is that even out there. And this person was supposedly trans for 11yrs. I'm bummed guys.

title: My view from the closet
body:
I have only recently begun to accept myself as nonbinary, and this community is really the only place I feel comfortable saying that.

I'm 40, and I don't know if I'll actually "come out" irl. I've tried to do a soft coming - out to my husband, saying "I'm not saying I'm definitely nonbinary, but, like, maybe I can see myself in that kind of way". And his knee-jerk reaction can be boiled down to "I hope you're not, cos I'm a straight man, and I thought I married a woman".

I'm not looking to change my body, or my clothes, or my relationship, or my name. I'm still just me. And I'd rather people address me as Mx instead of Mrs.
But I haven't actually let anyone know that about me.

And if I can't be straight (ha!) with my husband, I definitely won't be able to tell my parents. My mom takes things really personally, and has some old fashioned and conservative ideas around gender and sexuality. I'm afraid that if I open this particular can of worms, she's going to cry and act like she doesn't know who I am anymore. She is absolutely prone to overreacting.
I was diagnosed with diabetes when I was 15, and she wept and blamed herself.
When she "discovered" I had lost my virginity, she accused me of "ruining Christmas".

So I think "hey mom, your daughter isn't a woman" would blow her mind.

Anyhow I'll be peeking out at Pride from the closet! Hello!

title: I may have messed up today
body:
Disclaimer: I'm writing this directly after my work shift while I'm slightly intoxicated. Sorry for bad grammar and such.

Background: I work a low-level retail gig.  I'm not out at work because I live in a state that's harsh on anyone that is even remotely considered trans. However, I am in the process of a name change, for which I thank anyone at my job who uses my correct name. Usually a simple, "Thank you for remembering my name" because it positively reinforces them to continue. This has become something of a reflex since I don't want to angrily correct someone at my job, especially anyone in management.

Today, after that reflexive statement, my nicest manager asked me, "Are you ever going to tell us why" I replied, "Some of it is to heal from childhood trauma" which is both true and my default answer to anyone I'm never coming out to. 

\- I also added, "For the other reason, I'm not at liberty to say because of our current political climate."  I only said this because my guard was down, as this manager is wonderfully nice to me. She's even corrected the other managers over calling me by the correct name. ... She hinted that she understood what I was talking about. She made an analogy that a bag we sell is "blue," but if others found out the bag was "blue," they'd gossip. I nearly cried at the level of acceptance she was giving me. Still, I asked her to keep it between us, "I know what I just said could possibly answer why, and I ask for your digression" She said the conversation will be kept between us. This is the first time I've ever breathed a word about being anything other than cis in my place of work. I hope it doesn't come back to haunt me. 

Did I fuck up? There are very little protections for trans folk in my state, even though the company I work for has a "diversity clause" This job is currently my only source of income. If I lose it, I'll be job hunting amidst the Covid-19 panic.

title: For the first time in my life I cried happy tears today in regards to my gender.
body:
All this time I was wrestling with what my gender is and honestly I still don't know. 

I had passive thoughts of being girl since I was 12, actively questioning for 2 years (of those 7 months full dose mtf hrt) and I still don't know and I just realized that's ok.

My dysphoria is SUPER picky. In social context of functioning in society, I hate gender dividing. I don't associate with males, neither with females (altough when it comes down to it, I tend to lean more on a female spectrum, and simply put "bro" culture is something, I absolutely loathe), I also dislike my genitalia, I never wished for a penis, but I also don't mind being flat chested and moderately muscled, just not something over the top. In romantic releationship I like to sweep person of their feet and to be more dominant one. I like to be the protector and I like to be physically bigger/or same size, just enough for them to craddle in for a warm hug, when they are having a bad day. In bed on the other hand, I prefer to be super cuddly, more affectionate and overall more submisive.

I just know that I'm not CIS, because not a cis person feels like I do, that's pretty clear. Though recently I figured out that not many transwomen feel like I do as well. I still do have kinda strong male side about me and I certainly don't dislike the person I was before, neither I feel sad for that person.

I'm such a mixed bag, I'm starting to think I'm genderfluid or demigender rather than a transwoman. 

Though having a "cis" option off the table is so relieving I can't understand, how is that even possible. All I did is that I switched off the background noise "that I might just be some deluded man".

In a future I might present as a man (albeit feminine one, while still being enby), as I don't know where the wind will take me, but at least I know what I'm not.

title: anyone else just feel‚Ä¶ ridiculous?
body:
i feel guilty for making people call me pronouns that make no sense. i‚Äôm not an alien i‚Äôm a person (unfortunately) and i clearly look female anyways. it‚Äôs completely ridiculous to force people to call me anything other than he or she. i bet i just think i‚Äôm nb because of social media anyways, in a few years i‚Äôll be over this stupid phase.

i consider myself mostly male anyways. i‚Äôm not androgynous, i don‚Äôt look non-binary, i use he/him in addition to gender neutral pronouns, i dress like a boy. i wish i could just suck it up, pick a side, and be a real man.

title: Did anyone else think they were "secretly" intersex when they were younger?
body:
OK, I feel like this is a long-shot, but here goes: when I was a teenager, I had a lot of weird gender feelings/anxiety, and the way it manifested was feeling like I was secretly not really a girl (I'm AFAB), including sometimes worrying that I was intersex but just hadn't been "found out." In retrospect, there was no reason to believe this was true, but it was the 90s and I don't think I even knew about transgender people, much less nonbinary/genderqueer identities, so I think this was my way of conceptualizing the fact that I didn't really feel like either a girl or a boy.

This lasted a long time - I have a vivid memory of reading an excerpt from the novel Middlesex in my early twenties, where the main character discovers she is intersex, and feeling this pit in my stomach that this would happen to me.

(BTW, I apologize if this is offensive or hurtful to anyone who actually is intersex - I now know there's nothing wrong with being intersex, but again, at the time I had so little knowledge.)

title: Confused yet confident, but I have a question.
body:
So this is me rambling on about some stuff, I just really needed a place to share some thoughts and get some stuff off my chest and I thougt this would be the best place.

So I'll start off by saying I am a little confused and yet confident at the same time. I'm a 22 years old, male born person. Yet I don't really feel at ease calling myself male. I've always felt kind of in the middle of everything. Sort of a 60/40 mix...

Now as I've got older I think there's a big chance I'm nonbinary, or at least some form of it. (I guess I would be genderfluid?)
Ever since I've grown my hair out and lost quite a bit of weight I've started to really feel like myself. I even had someone mistake me for a woman when they drove by and catcalled me! Which I know not everyone enjoys, but being mistaken for a female (and a hot one at that) was, for me, a really great affirmation.
My ex did my make up once and it felt great. I also used to polish my nails but I've stopped doing that because of all the bad reactions I received from friends and family.

Now, the odd thing to me is that I really don't feel like myself without my beard. Is it weird for a nonbinary person, born male, to prefer keeping their beard?

As a bit of a sidenote, I love shaving my beard in different styles, especially things like a goatee or a van dyke.

Also too scared to post a pic because everyone here looks way more androgynous than I, such beautiful people on this sub!!!  >.<

Thanks for tolerating my rambling!

title: Weird thing....
body:
So I was watching a movie about a guy figuring out that he's gay.  And when he's kissing the other man I was like, that's a situation where I could feel comfortable with a man, if he perceived me as another man.

That felt a bit strange to me.  Anyone else experience a similar phenomenon, that their attractions vary based on their sense of where their gender expression is at and being perceived as?

title: My partner wants top surgery.
body:
Possible TW: Gender dysphoria 


I‚Äôm a trans woman in a 4 year relationship with an AFAB non-binary trans masc person. 
They have, over the past year, expressed interest in getting top surgery, and are pursuing it in earnest. They also have been on T for over a year.
I support this because I want them to feel comfortable in their own body, however, I do have at least a little sense of melancholy about it. 
Some of it is just the fact I love having breasts and feel a bit of envy for theirs, some of it is fear that my attraction to them will change after the surgery, as I‚Äôm very sapphic leaning.

We are serious partners with a child, I‚Äôm not going anywhere. I love them dearly and can‚Äôt picture life without them. 
I‚Äôm doing my best to deconstruct my perception of gender, internalized transphobia/enbyphobia(?) but is it wrong that I‚Äôm a little sad that something I appreciate about their body is going away?

I recognize I‚Äôm in no way entitled to their body or the choices they make with it.
It feels like maybe I‚Äôve still got some tendencies toward objectification. It feels shallow that I‚Äôm feeling this at all. 
The physical changes they‚Äôve experienced on T I‚Äôve found VERY attractive. I love the muscles, deeper voice and bottom growth. They know that I‚Äôm very excited by their particular flavor of ‚Äúbutch‚Äù transmasculinity.  

However, I don‚Äôt feel like this is something I could discuss with them without sullying their excitement for finally having the body they want. I believe this is my issue that I need to work through to be a supportive partner.
I‚Äôm just struggling with my own feelings and where they come from.

title: Love the idea of femboy, hate the idea of boy
body:
I love how femboys express themselves and I would really want to look like that.


BUT, I don't like the idea of being transmasc nor masc, boy, man, masculine in any way.


I feel lost again :(

title: I feel like a gay man (so frustrated)
body: I'm a assigned woman at birth and I'm into men only (straight). I feel like I truly wish I was born a boy. a gay boy. I have felt like this for so long and am so frustrated. it should be simple--I like men, many men like women. and I am one. so I should be happy.... but I don't want to BE a woman.

title: Does anyone else hate how pointlessly gendered razors are?
body:
I have to shave my facial hair and have tried ‚Äú‚Äùwomen‚Äôs razors‚Äù‚Äù because they usually come in more neutral colors (I mean...not by much, but something simple and purple appeals to me more than how overtly masculine the ‚Äú‚Äùmen‚Äôs razors‚Äù‚Äù tend to be). 

However, I find that I can only use them for one shave before it becomes painful. Apparently facial hair is so dense that it wears down the blades quicker. 

It just bothers me that I should have to pick based on that. I feel like I have to pick between patronizing marketing or marketing that makes me dysphoric (shaving my face is already rather masculine and I find that having a more feminine razor makes me feel more balanced about it.) 

I‚Äôm not really asking for advice, although if anyone has any, that‚Äôd be great. I just think it‚Äôs so stupid how something as simple as shaving is such a binaristic thing. :/

title: I'm coming out on Facebook tomorrow
body:
I'm super nervous, but I figured that if I don't do it now I'm just delaying the inevitable. I already came out in person to those that matter most to me, my boyfriend, my mother, his mother, my sister, and one close friend, and so far it's been taken really really well.

I have written up and revised my post for 2 weeks now. I'm ready to be patient with any questions anyone has, but I'm not going to tolerate any transphobia, and I'm prepared for those who don't agree with me existing unfriending me. 

I'm still so nervous. It's been giving me a stress headache all day.

-Avery (they/he)

title: Tried to defend trans people in comments, the ‚Äòphobes keep downvoting me
body:
Try to do something simple like say ‚Äúdisrespecting pronouns is transphobic, especially when you know someone‚Äôs pronouns‚Äù
That‚Äôs it. That‚Äôs all I said. If you do transphobic things, that‚Äôs a sign you‚Äôre a transphobe. 
I know that the rest of the world likes to pretend we don‚Äôt exist and have feelings about ‚Äúsilly‚Äù things like this but you‚Äôd never do it to a cis person. And it‚Äôs such a quick occurrence too. Literally less than 30mins and comments are already at -30ish votes. Someone has to be putting out a call when these kinds of comments get made. No other comments get downvoted as quickly as the ones that offend racists, sexists, and trans/homophobes. I probably shouldn‚Äôt even post this because they can just click on my profile and find out that their words do hurt, but they should know. They should know they‚Äôre causing harm and that real people read their words and those words have connotations and consequences. They should be ashamed of themselves. They should experience a modicum of empathy for once in their goddamn lives. Maybe this isn‚Äôt even the right sub for this but I needed to rant and I‚Äôm non-binary so it seemed to fit. 

I‚Äôll keep fighting the good fight but god it can be exhausting.

title: Wearing a binder to Christmas dinner and I'm scared
body: What is someone notices I suddenly have no tits?? I haven't worn it out for more then an hour before. But I really hate this outfit without it and I have nothing else to wear I feel comfortable in. This is stressing me out so much...

title: AMAB people can identify as demiboy, right?
body: I'm unsure of my identity right now, but I think I may be a demiboy. But I feel guilty about it, I feel like I'm just a cis guy pretending posing as a non-binary person, I feel like I'm faking it. I do use they/them pronouns, but I'm still fine with he/him pronouns. I'm just really going through a hard time with this.

title: Seriously reconsidering name change
body:
(transmasc enby, he/they)

I‚Äôve been using Roro as my name for over a year (initially it was just a nickname I used on the internet but I liked it too much). I truly wanted to make it my legal name, even though it‚Äôs not popular: there‚Äôs no info on it on Behind the Name, the only few examples are from Indonesia, and in my country (Poland) no one has it as the legal name.

Moreover, I feel like it‚Äôs not treated seriously at all. My mother, when I came out to her in February, asked if I‚Äôm ‚Äúliving in some hecking anime‚Äù. I feel like people feel weird using it and would rather stick to my deadname. My paranoia and anxiety only keeps kicking in because I feel like people don‚Äôt take me seriously when I tell them my name. That‚Äôs why I‚Äôve been considering name change, to something more ‚Äúacceptable‚Äù and less ‚Äúweird‚Äù.

On one hand, this feels like a safe option and this way, for example, I‚Äôd find it easier to introduce myself, without exposing myself to weirded out reactions. I think it‚Äôd also be easier to change my name if I pick something more popular and something that is more in use. But on the other hand, my partner really likes calling me Roro, and I suppose it‚Äôd be hard for them to change their habit.

I‚Äôm feeling worse and worse each day, I have no idea what to do. I can also send my pics in comments if that helps.

title: Four days into T, and some surprising results
body:
I've been on T (50mg gel) for four days and already there are two changes. One I expected - already there is measurable bottom growth. But the other really surprised me.

As a bi-gender person, I was *really* worried about the mental effects of T on my psyche. I really like my strong female side. I was worried the whole thing would fail because the T might give me terrible dysphoria. Instead, my mind is much calmer now, more relaxed, and I'm less likely to have freaked-out thoughts that, until last week, would go round and round in my head. My other emotions are quite solid and accessible, but they're no longer ruling me with fear and anxiety (which included anxiety over starting T). My husband says he believes this anxiety was dysphoria. Perhaps he's right.

So, maybe I really am doing the right thing to explore my male side through testosterone.

title: I'm so upset rn
body:
Not a rant but yeah. I was gifted a Spectrum Outfitters binder. I was so excited waiting for it to come in the mail. I followed their sizing guide and I'm an XL.

It. Doesn't. Fit. I can't even get it on. My shoulders are too broad. Also for anyone else looking to buy one just a heads up the material is a lot cheaper feeling than you'd expect. Like it feels like trying to put on a tent. So for $40+ that's really disappointing. While I love the sustainability aspect I expected a higher quality over all.

 But I'm more distraught at the fact that I waited and got so excited just to try it on immediately and find out my shoulders are too broad for it. Like legit sounded like I popped a seam or something barely stretching it. God I'm sad rn. I feel so bad for wasting someone else's money too.

title: Anyone else in the US really f**king scared right now?
body:
With everything going on with Roe v. Wade and all the anti-queer legislation out right now, I'm terrified that LGBTQ rights (including marriage equality) is next on the chopping block. My wife and I are seriously considering possible emigration to Canada.

Anyone else feeling weighed down with fear?

title: Do you think we are not taken seriously
body: Like, I know it's just a dumb video, but it describes us as just putting they/them in our bio just to show we are "part of the tribe" and that we dont have to change anything. Like I spend so long shaving, make up, and being sure I get my clothing right. Then to be boiled down to such a thing makes my blood boil with rage.

title: Could the lack of an ego maks someone feel nonbinary?
body: I don't have a super strong self identity. When I think about me as a person I don't think of a man or even a woman, or even a person, more like a spirit passing through, ya know? I consider myself super down to earth so it's like I don't even think about these things that often, but when I do it's like an empty jar would be the closest thing to what I feel like I am gender wise. When I'm referred to as male it feels.. very strange even though I've been one all my life. If identifying as NB were a more commonly accepted thing I'd do it but it's not so I normally don't bother, but when I sit and think about it I feel very nonbinary. I have long hair so many times I get called a girl which is always funny because people expect me to be offended. I never do because I don't cling into the idea of being a man like it's the only thing that matters. Quite the opposite.

title: My mom told me that my short hair makes me look like I have cancer
body:
I've been out to her for 2 years. 3-4 months ago I started just shaving my hair off when I got tired of it. It's cheap, gender affirming and it's really great for my sensory issues. I love it. 

My step dad said something about my hair and I got annoyed. My mother stepped in to tell me how it made me look like a cancer patient, and then went on to explain why. I told her I know that chemo affects the hair, but that I find it weird to look at someone with very short hair (I was never bald, just shaved to 3mm) and just assume they must have cancer. It annoys me even more that they would think that about me when they know my gender identity (she even said that she doesn't think that about bald men). 

I'm AFAB and not on hormones, which makes it all seem like "I see you as a woman and women are only bald when they are sick". 

I'm just so frustrated and sad that they make me feel like this. I'm spending Christmas with them tomorrow, so I can't even distance myself from them right now. 

Sorry for the vent. I needed some air

title: Deadnamed in an Obituary
body:
So, my grandfather died today. He died without knowing that I'm nonbinary and queer. He died without ever making any effort to know me at all. That's... fine, honestly. 

What really gets me is, despite going by the same name for 15 years, the rest of my family chose to deadname me rather than use either my name or even my legal name for the obituary. They chose my ultra-femme nickname from childhood. That's just... fantastic. 

And yet these people have the gall to guilt-trip me for not crossing the country for his funeral. It's unbelievable.

title: Frustrated because people assume things about my partner because I'm nonbinary
body:
I am open about my pronouns, and basically always introduce myself with pronouns whenever I meet someone. (And people still get it wrong constantly, but that's a different rant)

I am also open about the fact that I'm in a relationship, but often people assume that I'm a lesbian because of the way I look. So they assume my partner is either a woman or nonbinary. To be fair, this assumption isn't helped by the fact that I tend to use they/ them pronouns for my partner if I don't think his gender is relevant to the story I'm telling. My partner knows I do this and is fine with it. 

But it's irritating that people think they understand everything about me based on my looks or my pronouns/gender. Like recently at work, a couple of my coworkers started talking about birth control. I had missed something one of my coworkers said, so I asked her to repeat what she said. She looked awkward and said "well, it's not really important. We were talking about birth control, but that's not something you have to worry about." I must have looked confused, so she said "because you're not risking getting pregnant" She assumed that my partner was a cis woman. üò° I'm not a lesbian, I'm bi. I can date anyone I want,  including the wonderful man I love! Just because I'm queer doesn't mean that you can tell my partner's gender by looking at me!

It's never good to make blatant assumptions about someone's appearance or gender. And it's frustrating to constantly have to correct people from every angle. And when I do use my partner's pronouns from the beginning, people try to force me into the "women's role" extra hard. Like asking if my partner ever "helps me around the house" or if it's mostly me who does the cooking. They assume my partner is a "manly man" and ask what's his favorite football team (he doesn't like football much). I just wish people didn't assume things about my gender, my partner's gender, my sexuality, the nature of my relationship, anything! Or at least didn't voice their assumptions until they got an actual confirmation from the person in question, in this case me!

This was a really big, rambling rant. I'm honestly not sure how much of this made sense. I mostly just wanted to shout into the void.

title: Am I trans?
body:
I've been asked a few times if I'm trans and have no idea how to answer. I've been saying "I don't know?" and "sort of." 

Backing up a bit: I'm an AMAB genderfluid person that doesn't really care about pronouns and encourages the observer to decide what they want to call me on their own, based on the day or circumstances. Some days I look femme, but most days (because of work and stuff) I just look super normal with my stubble coming through, no makeup, and nondescript work clothes. I'm pretty masculine those days, but not necessarily by choice as much as default. I don't intend to do hormones, but I am going to vocal therapy to get a femme voice that I can use when I'm being more ladylike/possibly more often. I really really like PIV sex and am pretty accustomed to it, though I'm also down for any variation of gay stuff. I really like the dynamic I have with "straight" girls whenever that works out, and I'd hate to lose that in a full transition... Plus I'm pretty sure I don't want to go all the way into ladyhood by any metric.


Idk. That's kind of a big 4 am stream of consciousness rant, but I guess the fact that this question has come up multiple times and I still don't know how to answer is bothering me.

title: Coming out to my wife
body:
I've done it! üéâ

I've been questioning wtf has been going on in my little gender head for years. I've known something wasn't the same as everyone else but never had the words.

Background: Amab married (36yo) to afab (cis-het woman) 13y married and 2 kids.

I've been worried about how this would go down for weeks, would I find the right words? Is it better just to pretend I'm not NB? Am I throwing my life away? Would she understand?

So on a sunny Sunday morning I explained I wasn't sleeping well which through various situations we both know that's my body's reaction to a situation I can't resolve. She asked why, I took a deep breathe and said "I'm going to say things and just let me get it all out to it naturally ends". I then explained I'm Non-binary and what that meant for me (a rejection of gender norms for 'men', more colourful fashion and sometimes outfits where if a afab was wearing the same it would be fine but also if an amab was wearing the outfit it would be fine, pronouns still fine with he/him but a definite feeling of not belonging to 'man' or 'woman' but being loved by both ends of the spectrum).

We discussed what NB looked like for us, for me socially, how open I'd be (led by me, like I'm just never telling my parents for example but may well be out at work). Her concern was if it was a stepping stone to something more like trans-woman which (quite rightly) would be a different discussion. What helped here was asking my self some tough questions like "would medically transitioning to a woman help things?" "am I interested in masc / men?", I essentially asked myself everything, so I could answer any questions my wife had. This might be just how we work but it was good to be prepared. 

All in all it went well and feels so much better to be truthful once again.

Thank yous:
This sub is SO LOVING, just so so so loving. Every post I've read, every discussion is just full of love. You are all amazing, we struggle through but we do it with love and understanding and it's just beautiful. Thank you for being brilliant people. 

A person on this board reached out to me (or I to them I can't remember now!) and we've talked back and forth for weeks. We see life very similar and to talk to someone about everything has been awesome. U/sereneboi255  you are so lovely your partner is very lucky to have you. 

I never thought I'd get to this point. 

That's all - much love ‚ô•

title: Internal validation from an unlikely place
body:
So yesterday, my husband and I were talking about some sexual troubles we've been having. In the heat of the moment, he worded some things very poorly, and I thought he was telling me that he wasn't really attracted to me anymore and that he wanted me to be more feminine. I almost had a full-blown panic attack. What I basically heard was the love of my life, who I thought accepted me 110%, telling me that he no longer accepted me and wanted a woman.

I started bawling, telling him that I was sorry that I couldn't be what he wanted because I'm not a girl. 

He looked very alarmed and said, "Baby, it doesn't have to be all the time! It can be like roleplaying."

Me: "Oh... Oh. That's much better..."

It took me several minutes to get over that, but once I was, I started thinking...

I've been having some impostor syndrome feelings lately, mostly stemming from a lack of physical dysphoria. But when I thought I was being asked to be a girl and I nearly lost it, I figured that was a good indicator that I'm not faking it. So I guess a good thing came out of that.

Anyway, I just wanted to get that off my chest. Thanks for reading.

title: Anyone regret going on hormones?
body:
Hello, AFAB nonbinary person here. I started testosterone a couple weeks ago. I've had dysphoria about my curves and female presentation for years. I want to be perceived more neutral or even male. I anticipate this possibly changing throughout my hrt journey.

I've read some accounts of people who went from cis gender to trans binary to nonbinary, and took hrt to transition. For those folks I am curious if there's regret of transitioning on hormones? Hope this makes sense.. I'm having difficulty wording it right.

title: please help me feel like i did the right thing telling HR about blatant transphobia
body:
i work for a small, multi-million dollar a year company in a very affluent neighborhood in one of the largest cities in America (because as my manager put it: after looking at resumes for 6 months you were the only one even qualified and you were perfect [i was hired 1 day after my interview]).

my first day i was shown *all* bathrooms and my gender wasn't assumed by HR (im obviously gender-queer) so i felt comfy stating my pronouns. they used my pronouns in the "New Faces!" email, which i hadn't realized until this incident:

new hires take state mandatory sexual harassment and workplace harassment training; i took the same exact training as everyone else. i come back from lunch and hear the sexual harassment section of the training video playing loudly in the Project Manager's office; whatever they're always loud as fuck and annoying. however i could tell that the section they're on regards trans and non-binary individuals, and he was loudly joking about how he "really needed this training" to understand not to call B (fake trans person in training video) by "she." he then said something along the lines of how he """doesnt understand this non-binary shit""" and this training was actually making *him* uncomfortable...i assume because they normalize and respect trans people?

this is the part that got me the most fucked up: i couldn't recognize the first voice because a lot of these guys are new, but the second voice was a SUPERVISOR of the department, and he responded to this person mocking the training with "yeah i don't get this non-binary stuff either." YOU ARE A SUPERVISOR. YOU NEED TO RESPECT AND REFLECT THE VALUES OF THE COMPANY YOU REPRESENT AND INSTILL THAT IN YOUR TEAM. for him to flatly agree was just pathetic and i promptly stormed to HR, which was thankfully diverted by my beautiful and amazing lesbian coworker who understood my deep and angry "Come with me" as seriously as i was. she was deeply empathetic, called them assholes, calmed me down and helped me gather my shit together, and she came with me to HR with my written statement.

HR took me 100% seriously. they've actually had issues before regarding other trans coworkers and will "provide extra educational training on these topics as needed" which is HR speak for "ill hammer this shit into your head until you act right." the HR woman was floored, especially because this was during *training* so she was 100% ready to gather some informational packets and sit down with these chucklefucks for an additional hour until they're ready to be decent adults. she asked me specifically what i want out of this, i said just make it known that these topics are not a debate and reinforce that our company respects everyone and won't tolerate this blatant "queer-phobia" at all. i said if this happens again I will make it personal, which she completely understood.

i had to then talk to my manager, because she was also going to be made aware of the issue so i wanted to beat the punch: she apologized on their behalf (not necessary), and her and i just commiserated for 20 minutes behind her closed door about the blatant misogyny, homophobia and intolerance in our male-dominated field. it was nice of her to respect my identity yet also gently try to relate with the shit we've been through because of our AGAB. she also told me she corrects everyone on my pronouns behind my back ever since she saw the "New Faces!" email which had my pronouns. i could have almost cried; ive NEVER had someone stand up for me like that.

later the guy who i know made the comment comes up to our dept. and asks "who's 'Graphic Design'?" since that's neither my coworker nor i's title (dude FUCK these men!) and we both do some design work we both raised our hands. it's obvious he was just spoken to by HR and trying to figure out who said it, and my coworker is a real one for recognizing that and raising her hand too.

they're probably too old and oblivious to see the non-binary flag on my cubicle wall, let alone know what it is, and realize it was me. because they're dumb.

dumb dumbs. i should print our a bigger non-binary flag for my wall.

title: Uncertainty/Mixed Feelings
body:
Hi. I‚Äôm an AFAB teenager who has identified as non-binary (only online though) for just over a few months now. I‚Äôve been feeling some uncertainty.

My uncertainty comes from my feelings. I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôve ever properly considered myself a girl, woman, female etc., but I can find it easier to identify with women/girls compared to men, and sometimes even non-binary people. I feel some connection to being female, but not enough for me to ‚Äòfeel female‚Äô.

I don‚Äôt feel female, but part of me wants to be, at least in a way. As I‚Äôve said before, I can identify more with females and the struggles that women face societally, probably because I‚Äôm AFAB and have spent my whole life aligning myself with being female.

I‚Äôve had some people suggest that I‚Äôm a demigirl, but I realised it didn‚Äôt entirely suit me, because it identifies me as being partially female, which makes me uncomfortable.

The thing that caused me to identify as non-binary was my realisation that I was sometimes uncomfortable being seen as a woman, despite feeling as though I fit in with women societally. I suppose I don‚Äôt like feeling isolated from this group that I‚Äôve been a part of for my whole life. 

Also, I don‚Äôt mind having female/gendered terms used on me (sister, daughter, niece etc.). I don‚Äôt even mind being called a woman. Basically, it‚Äôs like I don‚Äôt mind being referred to as female provided i‚Äôm not perceived as a female.

It‚Äôs these mixed feelings that are confusing me.

title: Emirates didn't accept an X gender passport
body:
Hi folks. Emirates refused to let me board an international flight transiting through Dubai. I have an X Australian passport.

It was very distressing at the check in desk when they refused. I won't post what they said as it was pretty hostile.

Emirates gave me a refund but I had to buy expensive alternative flight through Heathrow with British Airways and Qantas. 
 
Posting to help people not make my mistake: both in choosing flight provider and X passport.

Im planning to get a binary passport soon. I pass. Life's easier.

title: Can I perform in drag?
body: Hey y‚Äôall, a few days ago my college had an orientation for LGBTQ+ students and I ended up meeting the drag club! I went to the meeting on Friday and it was lovely!! I‚Äôm going to perform and the first show is in about three weeks. I‚Äôm so beyond pumped to be performing again (used to be a theatre kid) but I‚Äôm also kinda second guessing myself. I‚Äôm non-binary, use they/them pronouns but am extremely femme presenting and afab (I‚Äôve heard that‚Äôs not a term that‚Äôs appropriate anymore but I‚Äôve also still seen it used, if it‚Äôs not correct please lemme know what I should update it too, I just haven‚Äôt been able to track it down myself yet!) so idk. Anyway I was going to mostly be a queen and do over the top femme looks but my self doubt kicked in and I worry about someone who looks the way I do doing a femme drag may not be right even though to me anything gendered masc or femme is outside of who I am on the daily and would be a ‚Äúcharacter/persona‚Äù sorta thing. I was just hoping to get some input, would it be ok if I did drag as a drag Queen or is that going to come across wrong?

title: Advice Please! Partner says I'm too femme to be NB
body:
Hi all! This past year I started exploring gender identities a bit more and realized I really identify with being nonbinary. I tried to talk to my partner about it but he immediately scoffed and said I'm much too feminine to be nonbinary and it must be my meds making me feel this way. The dismissal made me really sad and I questioned myself a lot, but it's been over a year and I still feel this way. I've been exploring my pronouns at work and my coworkers alternate between they/she when referring to me. I get giddy when someone refers to me as they or asks for my Pronouns. But I don't correct people when they use she because of what my partner said, and also my customer base at work is older and may get aggressive if I mention it. I feel like I'm being disingenuous to myself but also protecting myself from aggression or retaliation. 
Has anyone else felt this way? Does anyone have good resources for coming out at nonbinary? I have already come out as bi as a teen but this seems a lot scarier.

Thanks everyone and happy pride!

title: How to Job Hunt while Non-binary
body: I have been working at a private school the past two years and for safety reasons, decided to leave and find a teaching job. However, I had never considered that people would be wary to hire someone openly out as trans or apart of the LGBTQIA+ Community for fear of parent backlash (despite their workplace stating they‚Äôre equal opportunity). Does anyone have any advice for searching for jobs or any red flags I should be on the lookout for?

title: Is it normal to think about being a man so often
body: This will likely sound like the most obvious thing in the world to everyone who reads it. I imagine that I‚Äôll look at this in two years and think ‚Äúoh wow, he was really repressing himself back then.‚Äù But, like, I have socially transitioned twice: once at 14 to masc-leaning enby, and then again at 19 to a trans man. I‚Äôm currently living my cisgender life right now and I am constantly thinking and questioning myself. When I imagine my idealized future, I see myself as a man, and thinks get muddy and harder to imagine when I force the idea of being ‚Äúmyself‚Äù (a woman) onto that fantasy. If I could just magically have a more masculine figure and be seen as a fruity man, I would take that opportunity in a heartbeat. But the idea of transitioning in my current life makes me so uncomfortable. I‚Äôve already done it twice and I‚Äôve been driven away from it twice; the only way for it to stick is to physically transition, but what if I regret it? What if I realize that I am *actually* a cis woman or a more feminine person than my new body allows me to be? I don‚Äôt think that would happen but it‚Äôs not something that can be experimented with easily. I‚Äôm lucky enough that everyone in my life would accept it or already knows on some level. But I‚Äôm too scared to do anything about it. I need advice.

title: Anyone else thrown off by not fitting the NB stereotype?
body:
AFAB, age 22, nonbinary

I have been upsetty spaghetti about what I was bestowed with down below since I was like 5 or 6. And don't get me wrong, growing boobs was traumatic and all when my mom noticed they exist and told me I would have to start wearing bras, but its less of a thing and I don't care that much about them now and sometimes I like them or at least I did when they were a smidge smaller. Anyways, I just want to have a penis, It just seems better in everyway and I've kinda always wanted one. And I know everyone is valid no matter what way you are the way you are and all but I'm just putting this out there to see if anybody else is in my situation. Non-binary is so often portrayed as a thin, brunette, short-haired, white, AFAB baddy who binds or gets top surgery and is generally cool af. There are worse stereotypes but for such a diverse group, the lack of representation is hard. I am regularly questioning if I am just trans because I havnt heard jack shit about non-binary people who mainly just have bottom dysphoria. Where y'all at?

I am medium framed, white, have dark hair, AFAB, kinda sporty, quirky, (not cool AF tho) but really not helping the stereotype either, sorry I couldn't do more for the whole equal representation of all of us thing but this post is for all types of NB folks. But AMAB folks, those who want whatever parts, those who want no parts, whoever you are, whatever makes you nb, I'd like to hear about it if you are willing to share.

title: Question for 18+
body:
So this might be TMI but idk where else to ask it when I feel turned on I kinda wish I had a dick. Like I always imagine that I do and usually imagine myself being the giver not the receiver but it makes me sad that its hard to find someone who will ever understand that. I feel like I might never find someone who understands me.

Im genderfluid and have been feeling very genderless recently. 
I wish I had someone in my life that saw me as I see myself.

title: When do I get comfortable?
body:
Hello! This is a bit heavy, but I could really use some voices on the other side who've made it telling me I'll be ok.

I've known most my life that I don't enjoy being called feminine things, and I HATE being called "girlie, girl, lady, miss" etc. Since I was about 12 I think I knew deep down I was NB, or at least not cis. I've finally decided I'ma call myself NB, as a general title. While I know I'm not male, and I hate being thought of as female, NB still feels really scary and uncomfortable to title myself as. I know this is something a lot of people experience, the slight discomfort of something new even if it's the right direction. And things like my mom saying "girl- I mean dude" and such makes me so so happy, but also so anxious. Even typing this, I feel my heart racing.

TL;DR: I know I'm NB of sorts, but I'm not used to believing it myself, and thus anything to do with it makes me really anxious. When does this feeling start to die down (or at least not trigger when having gender euphoria), and how can I help myself feel comfortable with my identify faster?

Or just tell me you felt the same but it's so worth it and you're happy now haha. But for real, seeing all you older nonbinary people makes me so happy. Gives me hope that I can stick with being myself.

title: They/Them dilema
body: Hey, I recently came out to my gf as non-binary and she asked me about my pronouns but honestly I don't know. I don't think even they/them is something I feel identified with. Does anyone else feels this way? I think I could use it as a placeholder to not confuse people even further about who I am but like is there anything else I can use for my pronouns? I had never thought about this before and I feel kinda frustrated, like why can't I even identify with non-binary pronouns???

title: Considering T and top surgery but scared?
body:
Hi all! I‚Äôm a 20 y/o non binary afab person, and I‚Äôve kinda been thinking about T and/or top surgery for a while... but I‚Äôm scared of going through with either because I‚Äôm afraid I‚Äôll regret them, and the concept of altering my body in such drastic ways is intimidating to me. So permanent, you know? I know going on T doesn‚Äôt have to be permanent, if I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs for me I can stop, but idk I feel like I would be embarrassed if that happened? I don‚Äôt know why! Self-invalidation?

But while I feel these fears, I just really wish I had a boys body, not necessarily genitals, but a boys body type. I weirdly feel like I would be more comfortable with all aspects of my gender, including my femininity, if I had a boys body. I think I would feel more free to explore my femininity too with a boys body. I‚Äôm so jealous of my guy friends bodies, especially my lanky friends. And god, I wish my shoulders were more masculine and broad. I feel like I can‚Äôt imagine myself aging into adulthood with breasts my breasts and curves, and like now since I‚Äôm young I can sorta hide my body from myself in certain ways I won‚Äôt be able to when I old. I‚Äôm afraid my dysphoria will get worse as I get older. T and maybe top surgery feel inevitable to me, but I don‚Äôt know when I should do it/am scared to. **Does anyone else relate to these feelings or have related experiences?**

It‚Äôs so weird because I also think I have some internalized enby-phobia towards myself, like ‚Äúwhat if this is all just in my head and I *am* just being ridiculous and stupid?‚Äù But then I experience dysphoria, or maybe even gender euphoria if I‚Äôm feeling really good and secure about myself and my gender, and I‚Äôm like lol ofc this isn‚Äôt in my head this is so real. Ugh! This confusion and stuff sux so bad.

Okay well thank you for reading, happy New Years everyone lmao.

Claire

title: Has anyone here ever had the experience of NOT always knowing they were non-binary?
body:
I'm not really sure where to start with this question... 

I'm over 30 years old and have, for the most part, always been comfortable with my assigned at birth gender (m).  I also feel like I've had an incredibly present feminine side that I love about myself. I'm very self conscious about expressing it though because of how much unwanted attention it usually gets (for instance, I really like the way I look with more feminine styled clothes/earrings/etc). Most of the unwanted attention is usually pretty harmless but leaves me feeling like I have to explain myself.  And here's the thing - I just don't even know where to begin so I do whats easy and just conform to presenting as male.

For most of my life I didn't really know much about issues surrounding gender and sexuality.  I have a penis and *mostly* like women which seemed pretty normal and expected of me, so I just never questioned my identity beyond straight-male. I didn't know I could be anything other than "straight-male" or "gay-male" or "trans-women".  Out of the three, straight-male seemed to fit the best, but definitely not a perfect fit... Growing up, there was always people reminding me to not wear certain things because "those are for girls/women", or making comments about how "I'm sexually male, but intellectually female" (whatever that even means).       

There's things I genuinely like about being male, but I feel like presenting completely as male paints an incomplete portrait of who I am in my heart.  I find myself wishing the people around me would just reject my gender completely but don't know how to even begin asking that of people who have known me my whole life. How do I ask my partner to do that after being together for 10 years? I don't want people to see me as a woman, because I'm not, but I also don't feel like I always relate to being a man.  

I guess my question is - am I non binary if I mostly want to reject gender identity but still embrace things I like about my assigned at birth gender? Can I be born male and use they/he pronouns? Is gender even real?

tl;dr not sure if I'm nonbinary or just a guy with feminine thoughts... or maybe we're all just people? Any advice or wisdom would be appreciated.

title: how/when to come out to people at uni??
body:
so I'm starting university in a few days and I'm getting a bit stressy about when to tell people I'm enby and use they/them pronouns. I feel comfortable straight up telling the people on my course bc I've had some interaction with them via Facebook and they seem lovely, but I'm not sure what to do with my flatmates. As much as I've talked to them a little bit, I can't tell much about them and I'm worried about me telling them I use they/them pronouns and them not understanding/not being comfortable with it and then being alienated by them. I was thinking maybe get to know them a bit better over freshers week and then telling them when I've figured out what the sitch is, but that means I'd have to put up with being called she/her for that time which makes me feel pretty uncomfortable. Does anyone have any tips or advice for what I'm dealing with?? 

(thanks)

Also, any tips to avoid itching?! I‚Äôm nervous the itching
