title: Can we talk about safety? [cw - comments might discuss assault, discrimination etc.]
body:
So, I'm nonbinary, AMAB, bearded and like to wear dresses and skirts. Trouble is I don't *feel* particularly safe doing so in public, and I have no idea how well founded that fear actually is. With a beard and a feminine presentation I would be *obviously* gender non-conforming, in possibly the most transgressive way possible and I've just never seen other people doing that in public.

I'd really like to have an open discussion about safety and gender presentation, as it seems to be something we don't really talk about that much (for understandable reasons). It would make me feel more confident in how I present myself if I had some background in other peoples thoughts, feelings and experiences around this.

A few questions to start things off (answer any, all or none!):

* Where/when do you feel safe presenting in a gender-nonconforming way? Where/when do you feel unsafe?
* Have you ever experienced harassment/discrimination/assault because of the way you present?
* Do you take any specific safety precautions when presenting in a gender-nonconforming way?
* Do you ever deliberately try to "pass" as having a binary presentation?

I know this stuff is difficult to talk about, but to my mind it's a lot better to be open about it, where we can reassure/advise/comfort each other, than to have all of us living with our own private fears and doubts.

Thanks for any thoughts :)

title: Need Advice: Trying to make a decision about top surgery.
body:
Hello folks!
I have an appointment next month that will be a consultation for top surgery (yippee). I know for a fact I do not like my chest at all as it gives me a lot of dysphoria. That being said, I'm finding it hard to make a decision on exactly how flat I want to be. Do I want essentially a radical reduction with very little breast tissue left or do I want full top surgery and to be completely flat? On one hand I feel like I may regret going completely flat because what if I want a little titty every now and then? That being said, what if I still feel dysphoric after getting the radical reduction because I'm not completely flat? Is my desire to not want to be completely flat tied to an internalized fear that I wont be attractive to men? Truly, I got no idea what's going on. Does anyone have any tips that would help me come to a decision? I wish surgeries where like character customization segments in video games where I could try both before making a decision!

title: partner‚Äôs sister having a gender reveal this weekend
body:
background: 
i have been non binary for a couple years now but recently felt comfortable enough with my partner of five year‚Äôs family to share this information with them. they have consistently told me over the course of our relationship that i am a part of the family and made me feel very welcome. it was a big step for me and i thought about it a lot but it was getting harder being steeped in a gender that isn‚Äôt mine each time i saw them.

they are on the conservative side and gender is deeply engrained (even as far as having times where the women go to a winery while the men go to whiskey restaurants) but i truly thought it would go well. i was sadly mistaken.

his mom responded with questions about him being a father and a husband and how it would ever work and ‚Äúdoesn‚Äôt he want to have kids?‚Äù as an initial response and since then has taken it upon herself to share her griefs about me to him that she has clearly held in for years.

she has said that she thinks i‚Äôm seeking attention in the changes i‚Äôve made to myself over the past few years (shaving my head, getting more facial piercings, dressing in an androgynous way) and has also said that ‚Äúwe have talked about it in the past and had our concerns about nat‚Äù all while still being incredibly nice to my face. 

i have been fortunate enough that he has defended me but he has been put in a not great position and never had confrontation like this with his family.

i saw them before the holidays and they misgendered me the whole time, his mom even going as far as saying ‚Äúmiss natalie‚Äù. i go by nat now and even though they called me that plenty in the past five years, they‚Äôve switched to calling me natalie again. i decided after that to distance myself from them and told my partner that i can‚Äôt be the one he shares this info with about what they say about me. (he‚Äôs struggling with the realization that his family kinda sucks)

actual reason for posting:

his sister just announced her pregnancy and is having a gender reveal this weekend and im obviously not going but he is. i know this isn‚Äôt about me and my partner deserves to celebrate his sister‚Äôs pregnancy and cherish the fact that he will be an uncle but it all just feels like a slap in the face. 

i know it is not right to be angry at him and the situation bc it‚Äôs out of my control but with how his family has responded and treated me since learning, it just makes me feel sad.

i spent hours finding resources that she asked forexplain gender after he told his mom and i know it takes time to process the grasp that gender has on our society but it has hurt to be so dismissed.

tldr;
transphobic in-laws having gender reveal. needed to share this with someone who isn‚Äôt my partner‚Äî i don‚Äôt have therapy until tomorrow and my friends haven‚Äôt answered so alas i am here.

title: Nervous about top surgery...

title: Anyone got some advice?
body:
Hello! I recently realized I'm Nonbinary, and although my parents are very accepting they don't quite seem to understand. (To be clear: They are allies of the LGBTQ+ community and love me no matter what I am, but aren't very educated in this field.) As you can imagine, this has caused a few issues, and I was hoping someone here with more experience than me could offer some advice!

1) Preferred pronouns: I prefer to be referred to as they/them, but my parents still tend to refer to me by my biological sex/birth pronouns. It's more out of habit than anything else (Though my mother can't quite wrap her head around why an individual would want to refer to themselves using plural terms) but it feels quite invalidating each time. I know they mean nothing malicious, so I need a polite way to correct them!

2) Changing my name: One for the software/legal experts out there. Although I think my birth name\* is beautiful, it doesn't really fit who I am anymore (Not to mention that it's quite tied to one gender). I'm looking to change my legal name (see point 3) but haven't made a decision yet, and all my email accounts, Exam certificates etc. have my birth name on them. How can I change this?

3) Gender-neutral names: This is a fun one! Since I like to present as fairly androgynous, I'm looking for a fairly gender-neutral/nonbinary name, or a name that could go 'both ways' such as Sam. Currently, I go by a temporary transition name that's a contraction of my birth name (I've had enough nicknames that most people don't question it) but it's far from ideal... my favorite idea so far is 'Tawny' (after the owl) but I'd love to hear some others so I can try on various options from a list! 

4)Top surgery: Ah yes, the reason I marked this as 'NSFW'. I know I need top surgery (I won't go into detail, let's just say gender dysphoria is horrible and leave it at that) but I don't know where to begin looking. (For reference, I live in the UK so ideally I'd like to find it on the NHS) Is there anything I should know, such as length of waiting lists etc?

\*I have chosen to use the term 'Birth name' rather than 'Deadname' as I actually quite like my legal name (just not as MY name!) and because it is still in use at the moment- it's dying, not dead per se.

title: I'm tired of the romance whit a non-binary character in series
body:
Idk if this happened only to me, but I recently watched a lot of queer series, especially from my country (Italy), and it happened a lot of times that the non-gender-confirming character (usually a non-binary one), falls in love whit a straight cis man a bit homophobic who magically change his idea of queer people and the two of them live happily ever after. And this just make me angry because this is obviously for a straight cis audience who fetishizes queer people. And also this make me so "hopeless romantic" because I wish this could happen in real life, but is not that simple. 
I'm just tired of this, and wanted to ask if it ever happened to anyone else.

title: Perceived Feminity and "Acceptable" Plus Size Clothing: TikTok Trend "When I Hated My Body" Vs. "When I Loved It"
body:
I'm new to the sub so sorry if I make any mistakes! 

I've been seeing all these posts on Tik Tok from plus size creators (I'm plus size) of "when I hated my body I dressed like" and it's more baggy, non-feminine, modest clothes, and then it transitions to "verus how I dressed when I loved my body" and it's ultra-feminine, low cut, tight, revealing clothes. 

This trend specifically has really been affecting me (not the creators fault it just has). I only recently have come to realize that I don't believe I'm cis, and I was only dressing ultra feminine and revealing and such because I thought as a plus size person that was the only way I could be perceived as anything other than dirty and lazy.

I only recently have started to reject that and now show no cleavage and don't wear very many tight things as it really makes me uncomfortable with how feminine I get perceived when I do so My ideal presentation is I'd say right now is fluid on the spectrum between feminine and nothing with a drop or two of masculine, never reaching either point fully but fluctuating in between and always having balance.

I'm back to feeling gross and sloppy though after seeing this trend, and I wonder if anyone had any thoughts on it? I feel stuck because the way I want to dress (more feminine) doesn't match with my very "curvy" body, so instead I have to dress less feminine to feel more comfortable in my body, but then sometimes I think people see me as sloppy or lazy or insecure.

It's like because of my shape I wear oversized men's t shirts with bike shorts or huge pants and a high necked t shirt I tie to crop. But if I wasn't shaped this way I'd wear things like florals, or lower cut shirts (less cleavage lol) and maybe even dresss (it's been years haha) and such without feeling I'm too far on the spectrum.

But it feels like the only presentation I feel accessible it me right now makes people see me as hating myself and being lazy and dirty and to be honest ugly, as if the only way a plus size person can look desirable is through being hyper feminine

Any thoughts? Can anyone relate lol? Any tips on how to deal with this? Idk this is a rant/advice mix post haha.

title: Therapist advice
body: So I‚Äôm a high schooler, and I‚Äôve been wanting to go to therapy to try to make some sense of my gender (and a couple other things) but my mother will only set up the appointment if I tell her why I want to go. And I get that, therapy‚Äôs expensive, but I‚Äôm in the closet and I don‚Äôt want to tell her about the other mental stuff. She has a bad track record of taking anything I tell her I feel and making it seem either invalid or blown out of proportion or both. Any advice?

title: What animals or aesthetics do you immediately associate as having enby energy?
body:
Hi there! I'm a character creater and a they/them enby- I've drawn and created characters for as long as i can remember although only recently would I consider them good- 

But the longer I draw and make new characters, the more I want to have a character that'd fit as for an online version of myself

For a while I've gone by Cacty the Cactus and even now I use it for my watermark- but something about drawing the cactus became a bit weird for me. So i've tried making a buncha different characters that I could use to relate to myself- Raccoons, Possums, Both, Robots- all of them could work but they just don't feel right-

I've tried all sorts of aesthetics, although a lot are vintage/cottagecore/goblincore- but nothin seems to feel right to me.

So I humbly ask for your help lovely people of 
r/Nonbinary to help me properly express myself without feeling icky about it later-

TL;DR - What animals or aesthetics do you immediately associate as having enby energy?

title: Just beginning my journey, not sure how I want to present.
body:
I am biologically female (important for context), I'm in my early 20's and my body has developed with a very curvy and feminine figure. I absolutely hate it. I feel like my hips will always give me away and I will never be fully gender neutral in appearance the way I want to be. In my ideal world, when other people perceive me I would like them to think "person" instead of "woman" or "female". 

I have been wearing a non binary pin at work, and shortened my name to be more gender neutral. But I've continued to present in a "feminine" way. I don't know how to present in another way as of yet. And I feel a bit insecure about wearing the non binary pin and identifying as such at work bc I don't feel like other people think I'm valid due to my appearance. 

I have ideas about how I want to change things up, and I get really excited about them. But also really scared at the same time. I know making the changes I want to make will prompt questions from family (who I love dearly, but they don't really understand the non binary community) and I'm not ready to answere they're questions. I don't know what I'm doing, but I just know it makes me happy. 

I'm already a bit of a black sheep among them and I feel like it will make me even more "other". I'm also a bit scared because I feel like it will make it harder to find someone to love. But I know in my heart that it's right for me. 

So here is my questions/ what I would love advice on. 

- how does one present in a more gender ambiguous way with large hips? 

- how have you moved past fears you've had before/during evolving into your current self? 

- does being non binary make it harder to find love? 

If there is anyone out there that has had a similar experience, I would really appreciate any advice or words of wisdom. ‚ù§


UPDATE! 

A note to those who wrote to me: 

Hello! First I wanted to say thank you to everyone who took the time to read and/or comment. Your words of wisdom and kindness have impacted me more than you can know. 

After reading what you all wrote for me, It helped me to gain a better understanding of my newfound journey. And gave me new tools to use and boosted my confidence going forward. 

Thank you :) 


Onto the update, 

I have set up a hang out with my closest and most trusted friend to go window shopping with to try and find clothes that give me joy. And not worrying about what other ppl might think. I will be pursuing my own happiness. 

Also, after some research I realized I also wanted to start wearing chest binders. So I did some online shopping and it should be here soon! I'm very excited about it, and can't wait to start wearing it. I do understand that chest binding can be dangerous if not done properly, so don't worry. I bought myself a size larger than my true size, and only plan to wear it for a maximum of 6 hours or so a day, with breaks in between. I won't wear it while doing excersize or sleeping either. 

The last part of the update, is I am going to book myself a hair appointment to get something that makes me feel more like myself and more confident. 

That's all for now ‚ù§

- Blue Oracle

title: Family Obituary Misgenders/Deadnames my cousin
body:
So I (28F, cis+, bisexual) have a NB/Trans (31) cousin. My family is very good about not deadnaming them, but are on the whole pretty terrible at their pronouns. It sucks, and I always correct family meme bees when they get it wrong. 

My cousins and their mother hadn‚Äôt been on speaking terms for several years for a multitude of reasons, but this Thanksgiving they came to see the family and also to visit their mom in the hospital since the mom (my aunt) was terminally Ill. They had a good simple reconnection. The mom passed away a few days later.

The obituary just came out and was sent to the whole family, and it freaking misgenders AND deadname my cousin in it. I‚Äôm so torn up about this.

My cousin lives in a very different time zone and hasn‚Äôt seen it yet, but I am personally distraught over it. One, for my cousin‚Äôs behalf. It sucks so much for them, and I have lost my own share of family this year and this is a big deal. I keep copies of obituaries on my desks for my loved ones. Also, my partner is non-binary and not yet out and watching my cousins treatment has only doubled my concern for my partner‚Äôs treatment when they do.

I know it‚Äôs not my place to determine a reaction for my cousin, and I don‚Äôt want to cause a fight if the cuz doesn‚Äôt want it or doesn‚Äôt think it‚Äôs worth it. Those of you still connected with family, when do you want someone to come to your defense and when do you wish it had been let go? As a child of abuse I often wish things to be let go for my own safety and peace but also would love someone to defend me. Maybe it‚Äôs about being willing to defend, for the person and not for self righteous reasons? Idk, thoughts? I really just needed to vent but also love to learn/hear other perspectives. Cheers

title: It's hard to be a "non-passing" trans person
body:
I didn't know how else to phrase the title. But this is what's been on my mind recently. I am nonbinary demifluid (they/he) and I have a hard time with people misgendering me. It's gotten better since my top surgery in January, but it's not perfect. I try not to let it bother me. I try to remember that people who truly care about me respect my gender and pronouns. I try to remember that most people are still stuck in the gender binary. But I get so frustrated! And I keep getting told that "once you're on T for long enough, you won't get misgendered anymore." I'm not a trans man though.  I thought I was for a while, but I'm not. And I tried to go on T. It didn't feel right. I like my body the way that it is right now. I'm just exhausted that people constantly see my body as "woman." 

And the other thing that is infuriating is cis people who tell me "well it's an honest mistake" when I'm upset about being misgendered. That doesn't help! That basically tells me they still see me as a woman! Which makes me feel more dysphoric and uncomfortable!

I know there isn't a solution. I know I should just not care. I know I can't change the world. I just was hoping that some people might relate to this feeling.

title: Feeling discouraged about my dating life
body:
Hi! I'm Doug, I'm 17, AFAB, and I really have no idea what I am in terms of gender. I use they/them and he/him pronouns and I think the closest thing I can think of to describe me is "gender nonconforming". 

I'm into dudes. Straight guys wouldn't like me, gay guys wouldn't like me, and I know like, 2 bi guys. I wish I could casually date, but since I don't exactly fall into "girl" or "boy", I feel like I'm immediately marked off as not desirable? 

I dunno. I just feel really discouraged and that guys don't like me, or that I'm scaring them away with my identity. Does anyone else relate to feeling kind of hopeless?

title: Where to work?
body: I was wondering if you don't get constantly harassed and misgendered at work where do y'all work? I really like what I do but the drama and stress of how other people act towards me makes me consider doing something different.

title: I want to start HRT but don‚Äôt want breasts (I‚Äôm AMAB). Is this normal or even possible?
body:
So I‚Äôm AMAB and enby, and I think I‚Äôd really benefit from a bunch of the things that HRT provides. The fat redistribution around my hips and thighs, softer skin and hair (this is a big one), and less body hair I think would all really help me feel more comfortable with my body.

However the problem is I *really* don‚Äôt want any kind of breast development. I love my flat chest and think any growth there would actually make me more dysphoric.

I feel a bit lost with this, cause I can‚Äôt choose which effects HRT will give me, and whilst some will help with dysphoria, others will cause it ü•≤

Does anyone else feel similar? Is there anything at all I can do?

Thanks in advance ‚ù§Ô∏è

title: Cycling between feeling cis, non-binary and generally confused
body:
Apologies for this long confusing mess of ideas, but maybe some of you lovely folks can relate?

I‚Äôm AFAB and have been wrestling with my gender identity over the past few months. I seem to be cycling through this process of obsessing over my gender confusion and trying to find a label that feels right, become more confused and frustrated because nothing seems to exactly fit, decide to screw all the labels and just live my life, eventually become curious about or question my gender again, and repeat. It feels like I‚Äôm spinning my wheels and going nowhere. It‚Äôs exhausting. 

While I find that many non-binary people‚Äôs experiences (particularly agender/genderfluid), resonate with me, I don‚Äôt really experience dysphoria aside from mild social discomfort in certain situations ‚Äì most often when I feel I am being treated or viewed differently because I‚Äôm perceived as a woman. 

Generally, I attribute this to disliking performing typical gender roles and patriarchy and all that fun stuff, but on the other hand I sometimes find myself admiring certain male physical characteristics and fantasizing about having a flatter chest or a more masculine build/physique. I‚Äôm also attracted to men/masculinity, so this can be confusing as the distinction between attraction and admiration can feel pretty murky. I actually have similar admiration vs attraction confusion towards women too, and have started exploring the idea that I may be bi. 

Aside from the above, what leads me to suspect that I could be non-binary are:

* feelings of being disconnected and apathetic towards gender or identifying with man/woman
* Love for androgyny and gender non-conformity. I dress somewhat androgynously as I don‚Äôt shave, wear makeup, have a short haircut, and prefer loose-fitting clothing that doesn‚Äôt emphasize my chest and hips.
* Tendency to forget that others see me as a woman and sometimes feeling genderless/gender neutral
* Feel best when I can express myself and dress without feeling like I‚Äôm trying to present as masculine or feminine

At the same time, I don‚Äôt think I fit non-binary/trans narratives as I don‚Äôt want to change my body (I don‚Äôt even have an interest in getting a binder, wearing a sports bra feels good for me), I don‚Äôt want to change my name, and I‚Äôm cool with any pronouns. I‚Äôm also not entirely disconnected from being a woman/female as I‚Äôve lived my whole life as one, which has undoubtedly shaped my perspective and experiences. 

This leads to me believe that I‚Äôm most likely a cis woman that digs gender non-conformity and overthinks too much. I‚Äôm wary as well not to adopt marginalized identities that I don‚Äôt wholeheartedly feel that I belong to considering that I don‚Äôt share the same struggles with transition and dysphoria.

I suppose I‚Äôd feel alright describing myself as agender and/or non-binary, but not transgender. Although being transgender isn‚Äôt a requirement to identify as agender/non-binary, it appears that most people who do also consider themselves to be transgender. It seems that most people assume you are transgender if you identify as a non-binary person as well. I think that I‚Äôll end up just confusing and upsetting people by claiming to be non-binary but not trans. 

I‚Äôm not even sure how much I care much about being seen as non-binary by others. I honestly wonder if my desire to identify as a non-binary or queer person is more about justifying a sense of otherness that I‚Äôve felt since forever, rather than because I truly identify with those labels. All I know is that I keep obsessing and feeling anxious over it. I just want to feel at peace with myself.

I hope at least some of this made sense and if you can relate at all, I would love to hear about it!

title: I feel like such a faker
body:
I have been questioning my identity for a while now. I think I‚Äôm non-binary, but I‚Äôm hella confused. I was AFAB and have a strong interesting in looking more masculine in the future (when I‚Äôm in my own). I don‚Äôt any dysphoria, but I feel like I would be so much happier living with a more masculine appearance and not having to be just a woman or just a guy. 
  
    I started watching a trans guy YouTube channel for advice and knowledge about things like binding and T. I am not transgender but I wanted to look more/feel more masculine. I‚Äôm hoping to get top surgery/ start T in the future. I was really enjoying these videos until I got to one about a Transmasculine non-binary person on Instagram. 
   
   I have always had such a strong fear that I was just doing it ‚Äúfor attention‚Äù or to ‚Äúbe special‚Äù. Even though I have told nobody, and my parents would kill me if they ever found out. 
     
   So I‚Äôm watching the video and the YouTuber starts saying thing like  ‚ÄúYou HAVE to have dysphoria to transition, or else you‚Äôre just doing it for literally no reason.‚Äù ‚ÄúWhy would you EVER change your gender and go through these things if you didn‚Äôt have significant distress with your body.‚Äù Everyone in the comments and in the video we‚Äôre making fun of them saying that transmasculine is not real, like you‚Äôre either trans or you‚Äôre cis.
  
I was heart broken after hearing this. All my fear of faking it and doing it for attention came back. I had to stop watching because of how upset I got. I feel even more confused now.
 
I don‚Äôt understand why I can‚Äôt just be happy as just a girl or at least have a clear answer on who I want to be. Why I keep wanting to change myself even when I don‚Äôt have dysphoria. I just think I would be happier appearing more masculine. 
Does anyone else feel like this? Any advice would be greatly appreciated.

title: Can you have gender dysphoria and not know it?
body:
I posted this in another group but only got a handful of responses, posting here too in the hopes of additional advice from people who have a similar experience.


I'm not really sure how to phrase this so I apologize if this just turns into a word salad.


tl;dr could I possibly be trans and not realize I am even though I don't *feel* like I have dysphoria.


So, a lot of the experiences I've heard about before are the typical "I've known since I was a child," "I always wanted to be/ felt like a boy/girl," "I've always felt like I was in the wrong body." Obviously these are all super valid and I'm glad people are able to know and be so sure of themselves so young, my experiences are very different however. 


While I am nonbinary, I am afab and when I was young I always *felt* like I was a girl, I would get upset if people mistook me for a boy but I loved wearing baggy, more "boy" type clothes, always wanted super short hair and cut it down to about an inch long as soon as my mother couldn't forbid me to anymore. But I got so upset and defensive if someone accidentally called me 'sir.' I even got implants when i was 21 and went from a small B cup to a D so "it would be more obvious."


All this to say, I've had moments that make me question if I wasn't overcompensating to convince myself too? Like I've had times where I was straddling a guy just right and it looked almost as if his penis was actually mine, and it felt really good, but I've never had an issue with having a vagina. Or now, identifying as nonbinary, if I get called 'sir' I just instinctively deepen my voice a bit and go with it, and leave the interaction smiling that the other person genuinely thought I was a man.


I'm not really sure how to feel about how I feel, and I thought that nonbinary was the right fit, but idk if it's genderfluid, or trans, or something else I don't know about? All I really know is that I like looking more like what society sees as a stereotypical man, and I like the idea of having a penis and all, but I don't hate or have a problem with the parts I have now, though I have been considering having my implants removed and maybe I would want to just have a full top surgery when I do? 


Anyway, if you made it through this whole ramble, thank you for listening and  any advice would definitely be appreciated because I genuinely have no idea what I'm feeling and I would love to be able to understand myself better.

title: Greygender Questions
body:
Okay so I'm not sure where to start.

Greygender is a thing I very recently discovered and I'm trying to figure out if it fits me or not.

I've always been more of a "tomboy" girl growing up right? Like I've always been comfortable with she/her pronouns but I don't feel particularly feminine most of the time. As a kid I always had a pretty even mix of friends between guys and gals, and that remains true to this day. I don't really understand the concept of certain things or activities being tied to one gender or the other.

Some days I enjoy being more feminine, some days more masculine. I often feel uncomfortable in public dressing more masculine but I come from a small town and I'm afraid of the judgement.

Overall though, I just don't think I feel that my gender is something I have strong feelings towards but it's kind of hard to tell. Since I've never felt any other way maybe it's just the norm for everyone? 

I'm afraid to call myself greygender and end up changing my mind later or something. But I would love to have a word to use to describe myself other than "tomboy" because that's outdated and childish.

Does any of this make sense? I'd love to dicuss. Thank you lovelies for your time. 

-Alex

title: Would like some advice/support
body: I‚Äôm 14 years old and have identified as non binary since I was twelve, but for the past few months I‚Äôve been having some anxiety about the fact that before I discovered what non binary was and began considering it, I never showed any real signs, internal or external of not being a girl. I mean, I was always kind of androgynous but I never felt uncomfortable being called she/her, I often enjoyed presenting as more feminine, and I never had any kind of dysphoria. The reason this is concerning me is that I always hear people say that ‚Äúevery trans person they‚Äôve ever talked to had some sense/feeling that they were trans since they were a child, or at least a feeling of being uncomfortable with their birth gender‚Äù or that they knew they were a boy/girl/non binary since they were 3 years old, and I in no way had that experience. This is probably a stupid worry, but I‚Äôm just looking for some affirmation/advice so I can stop feeling like a fake. Thanks for readingüòÖ

title: Any NBs with big chests who don‚Äôt have chest dysphoria?
body: I am non binary and have big boobs. I‚Äôve gone to some gender diverse groups and talked to other NBs but all have been naturally flat-chested. I do not experience dysphoria with my chest, it just is. Essentially I was ‚Äúone of the guys‚Äù as a kid until I developed and then was gendered by everyone and lost my sense of belonging where I wanted to be and was constantly told I wasn‚Äôt doing my gender correctly. I don‚Äôt feel I am in the wrong body but I do feel that people have made incorrect assumptions based on my having breasts. I am asexual and unable to have children so my breasts have no sexual or biological use to me. I did have a breast reduction for chronic pain reasons and am now down to 42DD. Really I find having boobs annoying, they get in the way with sports and clothing and how people see me but I don‚Äôt feel the need to bind or have surgery (although I‚Äôll probably have another reduction for pain reasons). I haven‚Äôt found anyone else with large breasts who are NB and am trying to figure out whether they experience dysphoria or not or what their relationship to their boobs is. I wonder whether I can technically be NB without dysphoria or if others experience it too. I haven‚Äôt met anyone who can answer this yet. Thoughts?

title: help, afab enby struggles T-T
body:
ok, first. i currently have long, naturally curly hair (that i don't really take care of so its a frizzy, tangled mess) and i keep finding myself wondering how i'd look with shorter hair, therefore sorta wanting to try it. but the thing is, 1. i forget to take care of myself, including my hair, and i don't know how to take care of short hair; 2. what if i dont like it???; 3. my mom knows bout all of this but she really doesnt want me getting my hair cut because "people pay a lot of money" to have hair like mines. things ive been suggested are: wigs, and finding hairstyles that make my hair look shorter or more androgynous. i don't know what to do, give me tips please!

second. ive been thinking abt my chest(im afab). i dont want surgery, bc fear of pain. im scared of binding bc several things ive heard, including health concerns and possible pain. i also need guidance for this.

title: Tips for dresses that would limit da dysphoria?
body:
Hullo!

My sister's wedding is coming up next year (summer, hot). Now normally for a formal event like that I'd settle for a suit, but there's going to be a lot of family there that could make a whole big deal about it, I don't exactly want to pull the eye away from my bloodkin here. I'm still trying to find out what exactly the dresscode is going to be and look if she tells me "wear the frilliest pinkest thing imaginable with five million flowers" by GOD I'll do it, but in the meantime, I could still research and see if any silhouettes work right?

For additional silhouette building context I'm skinny as hell, wear circular glasses and have the kind of haircut that happens if you let a buzzcut grow out somewhat. In my day-to-day life, I feel most comfortable presenting in a kind of business casual masculine way but I still do catholic schoolgirl sometimes (Knees are left to the imagination). Number one layers enjoyer. You can tell I had my nonbinary awakening on 2015 tumblr.

title: My friend says genderfluid invalidates transgender
body:
Hi!
Ok so... I came out as genderfluid to my... Well, let's say friend. (former love interest if you will but uhh that's another story)

And he was not very accepting... He talked about how he feels like being genderfluid "misses the point", and makes transgender people seem like a joke... because apparently, according to him, you can't just "decide" if you're gonna be a boy or girl each day, like... what. do you really think it's a choice? oh today I'm gonna feel bad because my body is too feminine üòÄü•¥ c'mon. 

I know he's wrong but how do I show him that?? I'm so bad with words. I just want him to understand that some days I feel like a boy, some days I feel like a girl, and some others I feel like a genderless potato, so what?! He also kinda criticized bisexuality I think... but maybe that's just me misinterpreting his words... I don't know. 

Please help. How do I explain the non binary spectrum and why it is not harmful to transgender people..? 

thanks folks!

title: How did you meet your partner who support you?
body:
Yesterday, I wrote about my fear that I might be unlovable. However, I would like to try to believe that I can be loved and that I can be in a relationship where I feel accepted and don't feel pressured to change.

How did you meet your partner who understand that you are non-binary and love you for who you are, not for your AGAB, and don't try to make you a woman or a man because they are ashamed of being with a non-binary person and it's more convenient for them to be with woman or man? 
Did it take you long to find a supportive person? Is anyone here in a relationship with a cis person?

title: My name doesn‚Äôt feel like mine
body:
Hey everyone. So, I recently came out, and my friends and ex have been pretty heckin supportive, and have started calling me by my preferred name since. That has been, honestly, amazing for my self esteem, and as such I decided that, since I just moved like 10 hrs away from my old life, I could ask my new classmates to call me River. 

And, surprisingly, even the teachers are okay with it! 

But, strangely enough, the only one having trouble with it is... me. I feel comfortable but I‚Äôm not used to this and I get sporadic anxiety attacks thinking what would my parents say if they found out, or questioning if I made the right decision by coming out.

Anyone else have this issue? My name, the name I chose, still doesn‚Äôt feel like mine, even though I feel comfortable with it. I hope I wasn‚Äôt too vague. Thanks y‚Äôall 

Tl;dr: i came out and it feels weird to be called by my preferred name

title: Gender identity crisis
body: I've been questioning my gender for a good while now and have yet to come across a label that feels right. I'm AFAB yet don't feel entirely connected to femininity. I prefer they/them pronouns, but any are fine tbh. I like to express my gender in a bit more masculine way, baggy jeans and tees and such. I actually get a bit of gender euphoria when i get "mistaken" for a guy. I don't feel dysphoric in my body though, i like my long hair, sometimes use makeup and I don't bind. My identity doesn't fluctuate either. I also identify as oriented aroace (aegosexual, aroflux, omniromantic) if that matters. Any advice will be welcome!

title: All the hate towards us is making me Unstable.
body:
I have been seeing all of the hatred toward Trans/ENBY people, and it's really ruining my mental health a lot, especially on social media sites such as Twitter, Youtube, and Instagram. every time I hear news about certain laws passing, and all of this BS it makes me feel even more closeted and fearful for my life.

Also seeing a lot of negative posts and comments made toward Trans/ENBYs made me hella unstable for my well-being, to the point I have trouble falling asleep. At this point, I have no hope for humanity and would probably never come out to anyone close to me. I don't feel safe in this world due to all of the hate towards us.

title: I feel invalidated after a therapy session.
body:
I was telling a therapist recently about my ex being shamed for being non-binary and telling friends that I was his girlfriend. The therapist replied, "Well, what was he supposed to tell them?" I said he could have told them I was his partner. She said that it's difficult to be in a relationship with an "outsider" and often non-binary people feel best in a relationship with another non-binary person. I agree, because it is indeed difficult to come across someone cis hetero who would feel comfortable in a relationship with a non-binary person and would not try to turn that person cis. However, I know that such cases do happen. I find it very difficult to find a non-binary person who reciprocates my feelings. It is the same with LGBT people in general. I dream of a relationship with another nonbinary, but I can never find a person who also wants to be in a relationship with me. 

I will not elaborate on this relationship, but in the beginning it was perfect and he seemed 100% accepting of me and was not ashamed of it in front of others, that I‚Äôm nonbinary and only after some time it began to change. The breakup was painful and there were a lot of unpleasant words.  In any case, I felt deceived. I did not enter the relationship knowing that he would not accept me. I find it difficult to let go of a relationship after a long time, but I will work on this in therapy. 

Back on topic, I felt misunderstood when she said "Well, what was he supposed to tell them?". I'm a little sad now, because she hasn't heard the whole story of the relationship yet. I felt that, according to her, everything is fine with his behavior and I should not count on being treated well in a relationship, because in this world there is no place for being a nonbinary. My mother used to say similar texts to me and I also felt unimportant. I didn't expect this in a therapy session. He deceived me and it's not ok. 

A friend told me that the text was unprofessional and that I should talk to a therapist about it. She said she would never hide the fact that her partner is nonbinary. 

I just got a little disappointed, because the therapist is understanding about everything and I didn't expect her to be so opinionated. I hate the fact that I‚Äôm nonbinary. I'm starting to believe again that I'll be alone forever, and I guess I'm left with fwb relationships rather than romantic relationships. I started thinking about pretending to be someone I'm not, because it would be easier for other people, but not for me. I don't know what to think. I'll talk to the therapist about how I feel, but I'm just sad. I find it hard to believe that such an understanding and educated person could say such a thing to me. I wish it would just turn out that I misperceived what she said.

title: I can't stop thinking about committing
body:
Usually they are just disembodied thoughts but lately they have worsened and I'm starting to think about some methods when they are in my proximity.

The fact is that I can't deal with my life anymore. A life balanced between lying to everyone I know and trying to not go mad by staying true to myself.

A life where I keep thinking I am destined to lie or to remain invisible if I come out because for many people I, a nonbinary person, am not even possible. I am ashamed of myself constantly. I am ashamed of my birth name, I am ashamed that if I change that name I'll have to tell everyone and seem ridiculous and egocentric.

I still live with my parents in a rural town so lying about my identity is a constant. I wish I could live alone, but I don't know when that would be possible as I'm currently unemployed. 

All these struggles, that I am also ashamed of because I am so privileged and I could just shut up, are bringing me crazy. I don't know what to do or say anymore. I just wish more than ever to just stop existing because I think my problems outweigh the acts of good I could bring to the world.

I am constantly scared. I know I should break the closet and come out in hope of maybe someone that could think that I'm not completely crazy, to save myself, but I am so scared and so every day is painful.

title: Probably was a bad idea
body:
TL:DR  - AI thinks I‚Äôm trans 



This has been such a tough journey and a topic I‚Äôm honestly exhausted wrestling with. I have major self trust issues and often get paralysis trying to make life decisions, let alone something that impacts me like this. So often I‚Äôve wished I could just have someone look at the facts of my life and just tell yes or no - you are trans or you‚Äôre not. 

I‚Äôve joked with my therapist that if I was trialled, I would probably be convicted of being trans. 

I got the bright idea to put in my life‚Äôs details and this journey of gender identity questions into an AI as a ‚Äúhypothetical story‚Äù then asked it to analyze. I included all the info I have given my therapist in 2 years. Added extra things as the AI responded and made me think of more. Then went further with the bad idea and asked it for an a ‚Äúhypothetical, just-for-fun percentage guess as to this personals identity and sexuality. 

Not sure what to do with this. I want to laugh it off and say it‚Äôs silly (and probably a bad idea) to do that, and to laugh it off. The other part of me is torn and terrified with what to do with the AI assessment. 

AI said with all of my journey input, there was a 95% chance (hypothetically) the ‚Äúcharacter‚Äù in the ‚Äúhypothetical‚Äù story is trans/non-conforming.

What have I done. Don‚Äôt think I needed that bouncing around in my head.

title: I'm sad at my partner's reaction that I might be genderfluid
body:
I've been out as nonbinary for over a year now. Recently I started identifying as transmasc, and using he/they pronouns. But after a few weeks, I started feeling femme again, so I told my partner that I might be genderfluid. He's been having a hard time with me being transmasc, and got really excited that "girl Riley" wasn't gone. He said that he could be fine with "boy Riley" if it meant that he wasn't losing the person he fell in love with. . .

I know it should make me happy that he's finding acceptance in my identity, because I love him. But it makes me feel depressed. . . Because it means if I am either wrong about being genderfluid, or if I had been right about being transmasc, then he still wouldn't be able to accept me as I am. And it makes me wonder why I'm still doing this. If I am genderfluid, then there seem to be long periods between shifts. Sometimes days or weeks, maybe even months. And if he doesn't like "boy Riley" and is just waiting for "girl Riley" to come back, does that mean our relationship will fall apart every time I feel masc? I don't know how often I'll be femme, but I don't think it's going to be very often. I went an entire year switching between masc and neutral, and have only felt femme for a couple of days now.

I know I'm in a relationship with a straight man. And I know it's not his fault he's not attracted to masc people. But for weeks he's been saying that he thought he could come to accept me as masc. And at the first sign of "girl Riley" coming back, he jumped for joy. And that hurts. . .

title: Starting estrogen later today, haven't been able to sleep for 24 hours
body:
I am so nervoused and stressed, I started 25mg Spiro back on May 13th and it has been the best descision I have made so far this year. I just had my 2mg of estrodial filled out and it is ready for pick-up today, which I have to go anyway because I need a re-fill on my spiro

In the back or my mind, im paranoid, wondering wether or not this is the right path for me. So far the low dose spiro has changes that I am 99% sure are reversable, but Estrogen has affects that don't seem so reversable, or very hard to

Ive also been so stressed that I am cramming down energy drinks

I also was just looking at detransition stories because im a paranoid and insecure human, and I honestly couldn't really relate to any feeling the detransitioners had, maybe these things ive said are signs that im def not cis, idfk

Im very tired, but also can't sleep, I can't think right now lol

title: Officially leaving the Mormon church‚Ä¶
body:
**trigger warning ‚ö†Ô∏è transphobia, homophobia, abuse, slander**

The ward President of my local YSA, wants me to produce my medical records to him and if he finds evidence that the church claims to be sufficient enough to me being intersex, the church wants to force me to transition to female if I want to date guys at the ward. If the medical records aren‚Äôt sufficient enough they will classify me as transgender and treat me as a homosexual man and tell me I‚Äôm to be celibate and refrain from seeking relationships. He then accused me of being a predator and compared me to a pedophile. Come to find out someone, rumored to be someone I was romantically interested in , went to church leadership and made up a claim that I said I ‚Äúsee the ward as hunting ground for men.‚Äù Which I never said such a thing. I‚Äôm just looking for companionship like everyone else.

I‚Äôm not an active member, but what I‚Äôm most offended by is the predatory accusations. The ward President accused me of being predatory and compared me to a 25 year old man trying to have sexual relations with a 13 year old girl! And there are rumors going around stating I‚Äôm going around ‚Äúhunting‚Äù young men as thought I‚Äôm some kind of demon looking to ‚Äútake away young men‚Äôs salvation.‚Äù

I‚Äôm absolutely appalled, disgusted, and been distraught since last night when I found all this out. I‚Äôm never going back there again!

title: As a non-binary person, 95% of the time I regret ever being non-binary
body:
The hate we get just for existing is honestly frightening. We‚Äôre told we‚Äôre doing it for attention and we‚Äôre just playing pretend. We‚Äôre told it‚Äôs a ‚Äúchoice‚Äù. Each day I regret being who I am because of the stigma. It‚Äôs just so overpowering sometimes.

My pronouns are they/them. I get misgendered by my family EVERY SINGLE DAY. They say ‚Äúwe didn‚Äôt know‚Äù even though I tell them at least once a day. I don‚Äôt like reminding people EACH AND EVERY SINGLE DAY of my pronouns. It‚Äôs a waste of breath and it‚Äôs starting to piss me off.

My ex willingly misgendered me EVERY DAY, constantly reminding me that I‚Äôm a girl (I‚Äôm AFAB) and that there are only 2 genders and that I ‚Äúchose‚Äù to be non-binary. Everyone says accept yourself, but how am I supposed to do that when it‚Äôs literally everyone else against me?

Because of this, I‚Äôm actually starting to believe that I AM making this up for attention. I‚Äôve been gaslit by so many people about this bullcrap my whole life that I feel like I‚Äôm starting to gaslight myself (how does one even gaslight themselves?!) It‚Äôs come to the point where I constantly misgender myself in everyday situations. Dating is hard too because where I live, not many people are LGBT+, let alone non-binary.

The only thing good about being non-binary is my name. I have a gender-neutral name, so I don‚Äôt have to worry about deadnaming or anything.

title: What would you choose?
body:
I live in New York City and my family lives upstate. I‚Äôm currently having a hard time deciding whether to stay here or go, since we might be enacting essentially a lockdown of the city. Our state governor is currently against that idea, but that also might change at any time.

I live independently in my own apartment as a grad student. I don‚Äôt mind being here by myself. I‚Äôm actually enjoying it, really. I‚Äôm allowed to work from home and have been doing so, so I have a steady income so far.

I‚Äôd feel horrible if I decide to stay here and not go though. My mom worries a lot, and I know she‚Äôd want me to go stay with her and my family.  I love my mom and my sisters and I do miss them and I know they miss me too. Problem is that they are the only ones that honestly call me by my pronouns and actual name. It doesn‚Äôt matter to my stepdad or extended family on his side. Everyone misgenders me and deadnames me constantly even though I‚Äôve been out for 6 years. They are very conservative and are trump supporters, so I‚Äôm terrified to defend myself any time they start talking about anything trans related. I‚Äôm honestly tired of being expected to hide how I‚Äôm feeling by allowing people to treat me poorly just to make them more comfortable. Hell, my uncle even told my little sister (she‚Äôs 7) right in front of me that gender and sex are the same thing and that people who think differently are wrong as if he was trying to teach her to hate me. It‚Äôs not like I barely see these people: we are constantly around them. Even being home for a week for holidays just makes me feel like absolute garbage.

Before I‚Äôd just ignore it and try not to let it get to me personally. I‚Äôm tired of it though. It just makes me feel awful and sad and hurt because these people obviously don‚Äôt love or care about me enough to even call me the right name. I used to struggle with depression and anxiety and I have finally gotten to a good place about six months ago. I don‚Äôt want to start feeling that way again just because I‚Äôd be forced to be around people like that. I haven‚Äôt even told them I‚Äôm nonbinary. I only discovered that less than a year ago, since I used to think I was trans. I‚Äôm never going to tell them I‚Äôm nonbinary because getting the binary trans thing is already this difficult. I don‚Äôt want to make things worse. 

So I guess, what would you decide? Would you stay in New York City to keep yourself happy, or would you go stay with family upstate to avoid a potential lockdown and to make your mom happy?

title: gender identity and epilepsy
body: I have absence epilepsy but I dread going to hospital appointments because of the medication i take. When i started medication i had the option between epilim and lamotrogine but they put me on lamotrogine because i'm a WOMAN and i might want children when i'm older and it will deform the baby, it doesn't matter how many times i say i like women or i'm not going to have children because of anxiety they just don't listen they keep saying your a woman your a girl and it makes me so dysphoric because i'm not and its getting to the point where i refuse to take my medication cause just the thought of that makes me dysphoric.

title: I'm honestly scared
body:
I took down my flags that hang in front of my window. At night you can see the colors when the lights on.
I live in a small southern and mostly conservative town. I have stickers on my car and I'm going to take them down early in the morning.

I hope you all are safe and sound.

title: I hate how I can't cry
body: I'm a 16 yo AMAB genderfluid kid, pre everything for context. It's been almost two months since I first hatched and I've been getting a lot more sad episodes lately where something switches in my either caused by external or internal factors or just be random and I start feeling terrible and on the brink of tears. The worst part is that even if I'm in a place where I can cry, my body won't let me, so all I can feel is the pain of tears straining in my eyes and I can't release more than a few tears. It's aggravating and I absolutely hate it. It's just one of the minor but important to me problems of being an almost completely closeted trans kid.

title: This world isn‚Äôt safe for me.
body:
I don‚Äôt feel safe outside. I‚Äôm always anxious. Leaving my home guarantees I‚Äôll be stared and gawked at until I‚Äôm on the verge of breakdown at best. At worst I‚Äôll be verbally assaulted or physically beaten.
I can‚Äôt even leave my home. I‚Äôm never going to be able to be able to live openly as myself. I‚Äôm always going to have to hide who I am forever. Why does society hate us so much? What the fuck are we doing that is so damn wrong?
I really can‚Äôt deal with this anymore. I cry almost every night because I just feel trapped. I can‚Äôt play this act anymore. I‚Äôm just so drained. I‚Äôm not even enjoying dressing femme/androgynous anymore because it‚Äôs more anxiety provoking than it is affirming.

title: Can we talk about enbyphobia (/exorsexism) for a minute?
body: Hi all. I'm feeling a little down because of loved ones' and also the world's and also internalized enbyphobia / transphobia. Sometimes I just wanna say I'm a silly f\*g that needs to pick a side or just stop. Sometimes I feel like I'm forced to be my assigned gender because of family. Sometimes people, even supportive people, are funny in how they always like to say Mr. or Mrs. or whatever gendered language all the frickin time. Sometimes it's hard just to see myself for who I really am. Sometimes cisheteronormativity is like a sickness and it feels like everyone is destined to be some wife or husband and the world feels too closed-minded to even incorporate my real human life into it. I love all you people who are brave enough to stand up for who you are and be alive (which includes myself, I am proud of myself and how much I've learned). Thx.

title: My father won‚Äôt stop deadnaming me
body:
So‚Ä¶ I (21) went with name change a few months ago. My father told me that he would accept my new bame since it‚Äôs similar to my deadname but I shouldn‚Äôt expect him to be 100 % correct. He‚Äôs old for the change he said‚Ä¶ (but my grandma is older and she‚Äôs trying)

And he never started. I never told anything because I‚Äôm like ‚Äúok he‚Äôs adapting‚Äù but it‚Äôs just long enough for me and I just sadly vented to my mom. He promised that he‚Äôd try üò≠ my brother is doing the same since I never actually came out to him but his gf know‚Ä¶ it just hurts

title: A friend trying to help made me feel worse‚Ä¶
body:
**trigger warning possible transphobia and intersex erasure**

I was on the phone with my friend and I was telling him about how I made an appointment with an endocrinologist to help figure out my intersex identity and getting a karyotype test done. He just kept making excuses saying ‚Äúwell guys sometimes have voices like yours and have gyno so you might not be intersex.‚Äù No matter how many times I‚Äôve told him every detail about my body and I‚Äôm genuinely concerned and I want to know why my body is the way it is he just attributes it to ‚Äúpoor diet.‚Äù I have legitimate concerns I might have a rare case of Klinefelter syndrome and being short or possibly XX male syndrome, and he just wants to wave it off as me being paranoid. And when I said that when I‚Äôm clean shaven many misgender me as a woman he‚Äôs like ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know why that is because I think you make a pretty ugly woman. You look like a dude to me.‚Äù Which that upset me as I now feel ugly regardless of how people perceive my gender. I know he was trying to help but now I‚Äôm filled with a lot of anxiety and self doubt and wondering what if I am lying to myself about being intersex.

title: I don't know why I'm shy about feeling included in both mens and womens spaces when I'm genderfluid and androgyne
body:
I guess I've never really felt the need to be divided into either group, and on top of being genderfluid and androgyne I'm also autistic and so struggle to understand binary gender and it's division to begin with. 

I'm AFAB since it's relevant. But I feel embarrassed about wanting to be included in womens spaces or womens discussions because sometimes I don't feel worthy enough for those spaces or like I'm an invader. And in mens spaces I just don't feel welcomed at all, that I'm "too woman" for them and just trying to shoehorn my way in. 

I love being considered for both spaces, but then I feel so shameful when I try to consider myself as "one of the girls" and as "one of the boys". Not because of my own relationship with my gender, but because of societal expectations. I know that there's subs like "ask women" and "ask men" but I'm embarrassed to include myself in either because of how people might see me. I feel like I'll only feel even more isolated from womens spaces when I start hrt, but still too uncomfortable and not "man enough" to be in mens spaces. 

Nonbinary spaces just don't exist. There's no "ask enbies" and even if there was it'd be by enbies for enbies and inherently queer and not really casually comparable to the other two even if queer folx can participate in the other two. 

I guess I just feel so isolated and alone. I don't really see groups. I just see humans and I want to be included in their discussions. I don't like that they're basically clubs. I feel like I have some of the perspective of women, esp growing up AFAB and currently am not out so I'm still treated as a woman, and I feel like I have some of the perspective of men since I'm transmasc and want to be in masc spaces. 

I just don't feel good enough for either. Like either I need to be cis or binary trans and if I'm not then I'm not welcomed in the mens club or the womens club, even if my gender dictates that I should be. I wish I could be welcomed, I just am in so much despair from this binary world.

title: I hate being the canary in the coalmine of my workplace
body:
I'm agender (they/ them) and I normally don't care all that much about misgendering. I work a public facing job at a hotel and upset and confusion from guests makes wearing my pronoun pin complex to a degree where wearing it isn't usually worth the hassle that I will get from people.  My usual rule is if someone is going to be a recurring character in my life ie: a coworker, I will care about as much as someone getting called the wrong name, lots of patience.
I have a coworker who we will call X for the sake of privacy. X has a lot of issues in the workplace in general, including BO so bad that the scent lingers  hours after he's left on the office chair. X doesn't lock the doors when business is low and our elevators are not keyed to a button or guest keycards. X sits in the back and plays videos and games on his phone (audio on)  for much of his shift which directly precedes mine. 
X misgenders me which is not surprising given his general lack of consideration towards his colleagues. For the most part I try to ignore X's rudeness because our shifts only intersect for 15 minutes in which he is supposed to share updates about the hotel, and doesn't, instead sitting in the back on his phone. 

After the election X got bolder. He wanted to talk to me about the election results the day of, which I did not respond to and the next shift when I was bending over the cash drawer, farted in my face on purpose. (I cannot prove this to management because the camera doesn't have sound and I basically had a non-reaction where I just walked away to the front and pinched the bridge of nose because really that moment was unreal). I sent an email because X's odor was particularly bad that day and told management that I had eye pain from the smell. 

Recently we had an event where a man who has been trespassed from the property for violent behavior showed up and was behaving in an intimidating manner in the lobby, which of course was left unlocked. I asked the man to leave, which of course he didn't and continued to stomp around the lobby. 

X misgendered me "Dude, she told you to leave", while I was calling security.  

X then called our tresspasser nuts and left me by myself with the violent man and two guests in the lobby. The guests ended up convincing the trespasser to leave, and I locked the door. 

I shot off an email to our managers and GM, just said what happened, that X has never gendered me correctly and ignored my requests for correction, ignored my requests that he lock the door,  and does not pass down information, and has caused me physical discomfort with his odor. 

My managers had a meeting with me yesterday and the GM gave me the book "The Subtle Art of Not Giving a Fuck" and
just... I'm tired of having this same sort of interpersonal issue in all of the workplaces I've been in, where people perceive me as vulnerable because I've asked for something novel to them. I thought that moving away from the Midwest to Portland would help but it hasn't really changed anything to be able to have the correct gender marker on my ID. I think that X would likely be similarly gross to any other person that he perceived as vulnerable and I'm disappointed in my gay GM for basically telling me I should expect more of the same.

title: So tired to conform to societal non-binary stereotypes and expectations
body: Pressure to conform to societal ‚Äúnon-binary stereotypes‚Äù give me distress and sometimes makes my life completely unlivable. I used to be fine with my body, I used to even be proud of it, but now I feel constant shame about my body, because I‚Äôve changed nothing about it to prove that I‚Äôm truly non-binary. I don‚Äôt want to do anything with my body, my style, my interests, I want society to stop gendering everything in me, my body, my life. I want the world to hear me and adjust their understanding of me but instead I have this constant unbearable pressure to proof with every second of my existence that I‚Äôm who I‚Äôm. I just wanna cry, I‚Äôm so tired of this. Do they create these new "boxes" for us because they don't understand us at all?

title: I'm terrified
