title: I feel like my Queer Ex-Friend Group was pretty transphobic and maybe homophobic
body:
I kinda just need to have a little vent about this and I wasn‚Äôt really sure where to do it? When I came out as Bi several years ago I had a pretty strong friend group of all bi people- all in M-F relationships. The friend group was pretty supportive but no one really did much engagement in our local queer community outside of our group. No protesting, no going to Pride, no membership in queer affinity groups (this was grad school) and no friendships with other queer people. Which is fine, but I think is important context.

I noticed things were weird on a trip out of state when my best friend whose a lesbian (not from this group) was there and talking about her relationship with a woman and people became visually uncomfortable? None of them have ever been in non M-F relationships or had same-sex relationships.   Not that that in any way invalidates their sexuality. At one point one of the friends started insisting ‚Äúwell everyone is actually probably bi, so you never know‚Ä¶‚Äù and my best friend got defensive, for good reason. She said after the fact that she felt really uncomfortable and unwelcome around the group. 

A few months later, right before I came out as non-binary, one member of the friend group started making transphobic altright comments in my house. I started crying (it had been a bad month) and left the room. When I came back he was still going and I told him to stop. 
After this, a couple days later, I came out. I got some texts and an in person talk from one person that the group was upset with my reaction to his (transphobic) comments, and they all decided to end the friendships. There were a lot of other issues present that my husband has pointed out- a few of them had often lashed out at me and put me down and generally bullied me. But these were not‚Ä¶ light friendship. We‚Äôd been in each others weddings. This was devastating.

But I‚Äôm just struck being really horrified by how the biggest queer friendgroup I‚Äôve ever had all really seemed ok with his transphobic comments. 

I really didn‚Äôt expect them to end up cutting me out right after I came out. They‚Äôre the types that post for every social media protest about uplifting marginalized rights. But looking back I feel like a lot of the way they talked about their queerness felt more like an afterthought and less like I was part of a queer community that actually supported and uplifted each other. It‚Äôs just, incredibly disappointing. 

That‚Äôs all, there‚Äôs no levity, just lost my friends after I came out. Buuut I told my grandma and she‚Äôs super supportive and asked me if we could do drag together because she apparently used to be a drag King in the 90s?? Who knew? A silver lining.

title: I feel like a fraud
body:
Whenever I'm in LGBTQ spaces, I feel like a big ass cisposter and I'm always telling myself ¬®you're not supposed to be here, you identify as a cis guy like 35% of the time, you're stealing someone else's place and your bisexuality ? A fraud too, you wouldn't do anal sex with anyone, you're not androsexual enough !¬®

It's really tiring. I don't know who I am, am not out to anyone in my family, even the cousin with whom I share time and a hobby, for fear of being gaslight ans shunned and rejected and I mostly feel unsafe asking for someone's pronouns first or to give em myself because I fear to be surrounded by transphobes that would discriminate against me.

It's like, when I'm proud, I have less feelings of being non-binary and when I hide everything, I have feel more non-binary than before, and I don't know what to do about that.

title: Do you have the same thing?(maybe controversial/sensitive)
body:
Do you feel like horrible, depressed, af dysphoric when u're menstruating? 

Well I have it and it's horrible, like it reminds me that I'm less of a person that I am(which is being Enby) 
Ahhh i want to transition medically all ready but I dont have the funds to even live in a safe space.

title: Dealing with parents, feeling like garbage (x-post from r/genderqueer)
body:
Last night I had a dream that I came out to my parents and things went well. Now I'm awake and I feel like shit.

I love my parents, but I can't tell them about this. They've ranted to me about how "nonbinaries" don't exist, trans women are perverts, and goddamn it, dead name, shave your leg hair and start wearing less flannel (I'm AFAB btw).

I know it sounds like they're hot-headed, stubborn, and controlling - and they are. But they're also caring, funny, and empathetic, and the fact that I can't share this with them saddens me in such a fundamental way I can't even find the words for it. Even worse is that I'm living in fear - if they find out about this, I'm terrified that they'll be verbally abusive or even kick me out. (I'm a senior in high school, so that would pretty much destroy my future.)

Then I had that dream last night, where they found out on their own and were totally okay, and I'm just so sad. I hate hiding in my own home like this. I want so badly to be myself around the people I love, but I know that can't happen any time soon.

title: Having issues with the family restroom.
body:
Ive stopped using gendered restrooms after getting comments in the Women‚Äôs and basically jump-scaring guys in the Men‚Äôs. The mall I work at has family restrooms, which I‚Äôve been told I‚Äôm okay to use, and it was fine until the holidays rolled around, now with the increased security presence and shopper traffic. 

Few weeks ago, I got stopped by a security guard and told I‚Äôm not allowed to use it as a singleton. I told him that‚Äôs not his call and my supervisor rang the mall manager; told them not to let that happen again. Mall management said they wouldn‚Äôt. 

Then today, I was waiting outside the family restroom for my turn when two families, parents and children, cut me in line. I had no energy to defend myself, so I left and came back. When I finished there was a security guard waiting for me!!! They didn‚Äôt say anything, just looked me up and down and left. Someone fucking called security on me. 

I‚Äôm so frustrated. I cried in front of my coworkers, which was embarrassing, but they all have my back. We‚Äôre going to see if a store that has their own restroom will let me use their‚Äôs. I hate that I have to do that, though. I thought the single stall would be safe, but apparently I was mistaken.

title: ‚ÄúPreferred‚Äù Pronouns
body: A while ago, I came out as nonbinary to my dad (he‚Äôs a Republican) and he says he supports me and that I‚Äôm always welcome at his place. My mom is very supportive of my sexuality and gender identity and uses the correct pronouns; along with my sister. Although at Dad‚Äôs, he keeps referring to me as his daughter instead of his kid and uses she/her when he talks about me to Ann, my stepmom who I indescribably hate (mostly from asking a fuck-ton of questions about stuff and also a Republican). I also have a bit of an attitude problem towards them at their house and would act rude (this is very common throughout the week. This never happens at Mom‚Äôs house). I try to stay quiet and do whatever I need to do in the main floor before going to the solace of my room. I would frequently mess up and the rudeness would come out, both of them getting very upset or angry at me. They would tell me I‚Äôm the bad person who never treats them with respect and say they have to walk on eggshells to not make me angry meanwhile I do the same thing to not make them angry. Sometimes I just get overwhelmed by everything it comes out as frustration. I would sometimes say my irritability is from not being supported or not feeling welcome by them constantly misgendering me. They would give me the same talk every time I try to explain my side, telling me they won‚Äôt be using they/them for me and my ‚Äúpreferred‚Äù pronouns are their choice. I got this talk so much in the past, I just shut up and die inside a little each time they misgender me. I talk to Mom about the situation, Mom talks to Dad about it, Dad gets furious at me for not talking to him first.

title: Dysphoria as a feminine nonbinary person
body:
I'm AFAB but I really like my chest and femininity in general. I do, get bottom dysphoria though
I HATE having female genetallia. Half of the time I wish I had no genetailia and the othet half of the time I wish I had a penis.
I love this sub but it also makes me sad when I see so few people feeling what I'm feeling. A lot of AFAB nonbinary ppl are androgynous and want flat chests 
I feel alone even on this sub

title: Middle school kids can be jerks‚Ä¶
body:
So I‚Äôm a teacher, I am not exactly out about my gender/sexuality but do have a bit of a ‚Äúqueer‚Äù hairstyle‚Ä¶ 

I was doing a self portrait activity with a class, where they draw themselves, then toss it around and they have to find the person.  

Well someone drew a photo of someone with hair similar to mine, and wrote ‚ÄúI‚Äôm mean and scary‚Äù ‚ÄúI‚Äôm gay‚Äù and ‚ÄúI‚Äôm lesbian‚Äù ‚Ä¶ and then the kid who happened to find (or make up, not sure) this drawing goes around making a big deal of who he thinks it is, seemingly picking on various people in the class, and towards the end a big ‚Äúoh, I know, it‚Äôs YOU!!‚Äù  

I played it off the best I could (also not mine, I didn‚Äôt draw or participate) and took a pause to tell them if someone did that and wrote those facts about themselves that‚Äôs fine, but if someone else was trying to make a joke and/or be mean to someone else in the room then that wasn‚Äôt ok‚Ä¶ 

Ugh‚Ä¶ now I‚Äôm feeling frustrated and dysphoric about myself.  I‚Äôm still caught between wanting to be hyper defensive and still closeted/egged about myself in public.

title: had to leave my job today because hr refused to stop deadnaming me
body:
i (27AFAB) am pretty inconsolable right now. long story short, kept getting deadnamed at work despite putting my preferred name on my app. kept correcting everyone but kept getting the "whoops, it slipped". decided to talk to HR because it's been two days and i was so tired of being triggered left and right. 

verbatim, this was HR's assistant manager on the subject: 

"If you want people to call you something else then change your legal name. People can call you whatever they want to despite you telling them otherwise." 

i was completely fucking floored. baffled. this isn't my first job by far. it's NEVER been an issue. she said "it's your legal name, company policy, i can't help you." 

i told her it's never been an issue before at any other workplaces and she shrugged her shoulders. i said "what's the point of there being a preferred name on the application if you don't use it?"

she looked so BLANK. as if SHE was shocked. i felt like i was in the fucking twilight zone or an episode of black mirror. what the fuck? she was like, "i don't know. i don't know why we have that on there. you can tell people what you want to be called but they dont have to call you that."

i just cut the convo off and stormed off. later, once i'd collected myself i decided to get a hold of the HEAD of HR, thinking that what she told me couldn't POSSIBLY be company policy. literally on my first day in orientation they had an entire segment about inclusivity, sensitivity, gender, pronouns, sexual orientation, etc. 

well. the head of HR doubled down. adding, "well, your legal name is (so and so). if someone calls you that, you WILL answer to it." 

I saw fucking RED. i could not breathe. i hung up on her, had a panic attack that still hasn't quite dissipated. i don't think there's anything else i can do, but i'm so hurt and embarrassed. i can't stop crying. i'm so scared to apply for another job because this HR department has honestly traumatized me. i'm so scared of this happening again at another place. i don't know what to do.

title: Any NBs get dysphoric being on T for too long?
body:
I'm 1.5 years on T and post top surgery and I'm pretty happy with my appearence and voice as it is. I wanna stop T or at least go on a super low dose. But I'm holding off because I need to make a decision apropos of my eventual hysterectomy.

But just the thought of becoming MORE masculine is panic inducing in me and triggers intense dysphoria. I almost don't want to go outside because I'm afraid I'm too much of a man. I'm not a man I just kinda look like one and in filled with fear that I'm going to be on it too long and be too far transitioned.

title: My wife and I are separating
body:
This is my first post here, and I‚Äôm really just at a loss, physically, mentally, and emotionally. My wife and have been together for 9 years, but we‚Äôve decided that due to some reasons, we just need to let each other go. 
I‚Äôm devastated, and numb, like a rug was ripped out from under me.

title: I feel like I'm wasting my time try to look less masculine.
body:
Maybe it's my dysphoria telling me this.

Maybe it's the fact that we live in a gender society.

But I feel like I'll never get what I want.

I know, whatever I wear, whatever make up I'll put on, I'll still be seen as a boy.

I should stop dreaming and get back to reality.

My greatest fear is something that will always be there.

title: [ED TW] I feel like I have to be thin to be nonbinary.
body: My first attempt at finding a gender therapist, she insisted that all of my gender dysphoria was really caused by my weight. And that my desire to change things about me (like my voice, chest, body hair) are secretly rooted in a desire to look different in general, i.e. to lose weight. All of my doctors just talk about losing weight, more so than they talk about things like my schizophrenia. I just feel worthless because of it and as someone who considers himself recovered from an eating disorder, I'm seriously considering kicking it up again. I'll never pass if I look like this.

title: Reverse gender dysphoria????
body:
I'm not sure what else to title it but I'll expand on it here.

I'm 24, almost 2 years on T, and I am so much happier with my body. However, the social aspect of my transition isn't going as expected. I thought being seen as a man wouldn't be ideal, but it would be better than being seen as a woman. It's been around a month since I started to pass as a man most of the time and surprise! It's not. It's equally dysphoria inducing. It's equally uncomfortable and still makes me want to rip all the meat off my bones and say "am I a person to you now? With only my skeleton visible, can you now see the human in me before seeing a gender?"

I went through a brief few months where people were thinking I'm male and female in roughly equal proportions, and a lot of people were working carefully to use non gendered language for me because they just weren't sure and didn't want to appear rude by asking. Those few months were socially the best time of my life. 

I don't want to stop T. I am loving the changes and I'm not ready for any of that to slow down or reverse. My physical dysphoria is at an all time low and still continuously getting lower as I get more and more changes. I like my T and what it's doing to me. I don't want androgyny at the cost of my feelings of safety in my own body.

But I am not a man! And I am not a woman! And I want people to see ME before they see a man or a woman. I love being perceived. I love being in the limelight. I don't want to tone myself down and become unnoticeable just to avoid being perceived as a binary gender. I want to be seen. I want to be visible but I want to be visible without gender. I want to be seen, for once, through a lens that doesn't include people putting me in a gendered box.

I truly thought being perceived 100% as a man would be less uncomfortable than being perceived 100% as a woman, but it is not. It is equally distressing. I wish people could see the human in me before categorizing me as male or female.

title: Guilt over not being nb/trans enough
body:
My husband knows I‚Äôm NB but not many other people know. I don‚Äôt have many people in my life because I‚Äôm disabled and kind of a hermit. 

I have a lot of guilt over not being NB ‚Äúenough‚Äù. I got married six months ago in a dress even though it didn‚Äôt really align with me. I liked the dress initially, but over time I felt weird about it. I was just so nervous to see family (mostly super religious) and old friends and to be married in front of people that I didn‚Äôt have the energy to deal with any questions on my wedding. I feel like I may have let myself down.

My husband uses my they/them pronouns but I haven‚Äôt really asked anyone else. When new people ask my pronouns I say they/them, but I‚Äôm still too embarrassed to ask my friends that I do not live near and only talk over text/calls. I have a lot of trauma from when I initially came out as bisexual to my parents. Now, because of what they said to me, it is hard for me to be myself to people for fear of being ‚Äúattention seeking‚Äù and ‚Äúoversharing‚Äù. Telling my parents is definitely out of the question.

I also feel that because I‚Äôm afab that more binary trans people already dislike me or think that I‚Äôm attention seeking. I feel excluded. I‚Äôve even had my breasts reduced (-10 lbs!) for mostly gender reasons. I used to wear my hair buzzed. But I still have a very feminine body and it feels like that‚Äôs all what people see.

And on top of this I want to go on T gel for bottom growth but I‚Äôm scared that my parents will notice my voice change. Or just random people for that matter. I live in a supposedly purple state but it seems pretty republican to me. Somehow seems even more republican than the red state I lived in last. And the anti trans rhetoric rn is insane and I worry that it‚Äôs not safe to be more out. But at the same time I feel like not being out is the cowardly thing to do. I feel invalid because I haven‚Äôt socially or physically transitioned that much.

title: Would it be hard to get breast reduction?
body: I have like, a b cup so they're already pretty small, but having breasts makes me wanna kms so I want them to go down to an A or a B. I'm 18 btw.

title: Bullied back into the closet
body: I had tried coming out and being more open about my non-binary status. I am fortunate to work for a company that is an equal opportunity employer, has pride events, and no discrimination policies. Unfortunately this doesn‚Äôt stop coworkers from being discriminatory behind closed doors. I work in the OR. I‚Äôve had a doctor during surgery go on a tangent of his hatred of trans people, saying they are all mentally ill, and he will refuse to recognize them by their preferred pronouns and names. He also said he wished we could segregate the LGBTQ community from the rest of society so that the cis/straight people ‚Äúwon‚Äôt have our lifestyles shoved down their throats‚Äù. It‚Äôs disgusting. I felt so helpless because this doctor had the power to ruin my career if I were to report him. I have no real recourse. I‚Äôve also had other people make insensitive comments here and there, and I try to chalk it up to them simply not understanding but it seems they don‚Äôt want to even try to learn or understand. I wear a they/them badge clip. When I first started wearing it my coworkers asked me if those were my pronouns and I said yes. They proceeded to still call me she/her without even trying to call me by my preferred pronouns and have never attempted to use them. This I can live with because I‚Äôve gone my whole life being called she/her but it would be nice to be recognized and have someone at least try to acknowledge me for me. Yesterday was the last straw. Another coworker went on a tangent about how trans people are fake and he won‚Äôt respect them. I wasn‚Äôt able to leave the room. After that I no longer feel safe being open about being non-binary. So today I‚Äôm removing my pronoun clips and just going back into the closet where my interactions with most people will be minimal aside from work. I don‚Äôt want to risk someone attacking or following me because I exist and they don‚Äôt like it.

title: My dad just wished me a merry christmas solely as an excuse to deadname me
body:
I just got a message from my sperm donor saying "Merry Christmas deadname"

He had every opportunity to correct that, to not send the message, to try a little harder. He chose the words he knew would hurt me. Merry fucking Christmas, I'm getting my mom to walk me down to aisle.

title: Surgery was cancelled and I don't know how to cope
body:
I'm neutrois and 23 years old. I've been out for 7 years, since I was 16. I've been waiting for surgery since I was 18. I was rejected from the NHS 2 and a half years ago and since then I've been saving up to go private because I knew I couldn't manage waiting on the NHS all over again, potentially for them to tell me again that I'm not a real transsexual and my surgery isn't possible

I was due for private surgery in South Korea on 10th May. It was cancelled a week before I was due to leave and in a really weird way by the surgeon. I've been given new dates in July, but based on the weird emails I've had it's uncertain whether it's going to happen and it doesn't even seem like I should trust the surgeon at all

I've tried looking for more surgeons, even though when I was emailing around the world a year ago this was the only one who said he could do it. I found a Belgium research surgeon who has given me a consultation but I've just had back today that the waiting list for pre-op appointments is 1 and a half years... I cannot make it until then

I'm so afraid about what is going to happen. I just want this to be over desperately. I'm so dysphoric and I've only just about managed the past year by having 10th May in my head as an end to transition

I wish so much I was trans binary - or at least non-binary but wanting to be the opposite sex. I envy non-dysphoric trans people so much and I feel so alienated from other non-binary people because I've never met another enby with severe gender dysphoria like this. I'm scared wanting this type of surgery is just delusional. I feel like an abberration, but having neither genitals is the only way I can imagine being able to bear interacting with that area. Sorry for the tmi, but I'm so desperate to be able to be intimate with my boyfriend. I already had one relationship crash and burn last year because I was so dysphoric and I can't see how I can make this new one work for long while pre-op

Soon I'll be entering my mid-twenties still stuck with the wrong kind of body, unable to do basic things most people have been doing since their teens. I can't face more years of just waiting for surgery and living this half-life. I've felt so broken and empty, literally just existing to work and make money so I can afford it, totally unable to focus on anything more mentally taxing and unable to enjoy anything. These last couple of weeks have felt like I'm trapped in a nightmare. I don't think I can make it beyond the next few months

title: I‚Äôm Struggling.
body: I‚Äôm pretty certain I‚Äôm nonbinary, but as a highly analytical and sciencey person I‚Äôm struggling with a 24/7 argument in my head trying to find concrete proof of the fact. Has anyone else been through this and gotten through it? Could you give any tips of how I can stop the internal debate and accept it? On another unrelated topic- how long after you realised you were nonbinary did you come out? Any response to any of this is massively appreciated because this is really quite awful x

title: What are your transition plans? Do you have a clear view of what you want or not? This is mine:
body:
I feel like telling someone because I'm feeling very sad and not valid but I am very sure of what I want and I feel like writing it and reading what other people want too will make me feel better and less alone. 

I want to change my name and add a new one, I want to change my gender on the documents on X (but I can't because my nation doesn't allow it), I want people to only use he/him in italian (there's no they/them) and he/they in english.

I want HRT so bad (I was AFAB), I want all the changes it can give me: body fat distribuition change, more muscle mass/strenght, more body hair, facial hair (I want a beard so much), bottom growth, the voice drop (omg please yes). I am a bit worried about vaginal atrophy (but I can keep it in check) and about hair loss (but I'll cope with that, I need everything else). 

I want to buy a binder, and a swimsuit that doesn't make me feel dysphoric (if it exists) and I want to go out without shaving and not caring about what people think.

I want meta without scrotoplasty but with URL so I can piss from my dick and it's hopefully big enough for some kind of penetration (ofc this isn't easy to know, but a person can dream). Not having a dick is probably my biggest body disphoria.  
  
I want people to be confused when they see me, I want them to stop be like "oh woman hello miss girly girl blablabla", I'd rather they assume I'm a man with boobs if they have to choose, but more than all I want to just be myself and stop being able to do so only in my little circle of friends, I love them to the moon and back but I'm so tired, this is not enough, this will never be enough...

I hope all of you will have everything you want and need asap, and if you don't know yet: don't worry, you're not late, it doesn't matter your age. You're not weird, not everyone understands right away, you're someone that is still discovering themself and that is fine, that's ok and normal and you deserve the time to think about it, as long as you need to.

title: Anyone else struggle with feeling self conscious about stereotypical AGAB traits?
body:
Idk really how to put into words what I'm feeling but I'll try. I'll preface this by saying I know I have a lot of internal transphobia (25 years of religious trauma) 

So I had an epiphany today that the reason I feel so embarrassed about myself and afraid to come out at work and also afraid to take more visible steps to present how I feel is that I feel so embarrassed about the traits I have/don't want to change that are stereotypical of my AGAB. Or more directly, masculine traits. I don't care about makeup, I don't want to voice train, I like wearing mostly the same style I did before with some changes into more feminine clothing. I don't feel drawn to either gender, more so I feel drawn to femininity. But I feel drawn to femininity in the way that a tomboy is feminine, but then I get so self conscious cuz everyone just reads me as a cis man and I feel like they always will. But then I don't care about a lot of the stereotypical feminine stuff. 

Idk really what I'm even looking for maybe I'm just venting and lamenting that society at large doesn't know my true inner world (no one does i guess) and so I feel doomed to come across to people as something I'm not. Does anyone get what I'm saying and relate?

title: I was assaulted today and I'm scared for the future (TW: sexual harassment)
body:
I came out as a trans man at 13. I always knew I was nonbinary, but I tried to come at as bigender early in my social transition, and everyone rejected me. I was androgynous before T because of untreated PCOS, so I never had a huge issue passing as male if I put a little effort in. I've been harassed and abused by partners and people who know I'm trans, but I didn't get much flak from random cis men because they used to think I'm one of them, unless they think I'm gay. Even then, it's never been this bad.

Every time I've presented as anything but a typical cis guy, I get relentlessly baraged with harassment. I don't know why. Most of them seem to want to have sex with me. I presented more femininely from 16-17 and got hit on by my dad's male friends, as well as by totally random older men. I have now officially come out as nonbinary and am dressing how I want. I already have a very distinctive appearance that I cannot change, and I have added hair dye and new clothes with different cuts and accessories to my look. I don't look or sound like a cis woman. I love my appearance now, and I'm having so much fun, but people look at me more than I want. I'm not sure if they think I'm a butch woman, a feminine man, a trans woman, or a trans man, but they know I'm queer. I've thought about making myself look masculine again, or at least dress casual, but I don't want to! I would be so sad.

I had a date with a woman scheduled today. I was taking the bus, and a big guy sat beside me even though there were lots of seats. He reeked. Not of B.O., but of the same smell (?) as other people who have harassed me. He said a lot of homophobic, sexual things and pushed me. He shoved his hands in my face, and I grabbed his phone (he was trying to write slurs on his Notes app and show me) and threw it across the bus. The driver made him stand, but didn't kick him off. He kept talking about me and calling me Satanic (already got Calvinist Guilt, so thanks?), and the other people told him to shut up. He still kept going. 

I'm safe. I went to a caf√© I'm familiar with, and they let me hide. There were these two very muscular people who stayed until I got into my Uber. My friends have all rallied around me.But I'm shaken and sad. I feel like giving up. I want to look how I want, but I feel like all the horrible people see me as a target. I live in a very progressive area, but I'm scared now, just as I was when I've been followed or threatened years before. I feel like I can never escape. If I don't dress in jeans and a T-shirt or something like that, I get followed and harassed and assaulted. It feels like I can't even go to my favorite fried chicken place without being stalked by scary people, or walk down the street without men calling out to me.

Is there any light at the end of the tunnel? I feel awful. I feel like I'll never be safe from sexual harassment and assault as long as I live. Can I never be androgynous and happy?

title: Should I stay in this chorus?
body: I‚Äôm gnc enby, she/they, and I just joined a chorus in my city. The manager sent out the handbook a couple of weeks ago which includes concert attire policy. Everything is VERY gendered, which is a bit irksome but I feel like I could deal with that (I‚Äôm not bothered by being referred to as a ‚Äúwoman‚Äù even though I don‚Äôt really see myself that way). The women‚Äôs attire is a floor length black dress and a string of pearls. When I saw that I immediately responded to the manager asking if I could wear the ‚Äúmen‚Äôs‚Äù attire, as wearing that dress would make me experience gender dysphoria and severe anxiety. Today, I got a call from one of the conductors. I was told the chorus is considering changing their policy in the future, but for now I would have to wear the dress if I wanted to participate this season for ‚Äúuniformity‚Äù. I‚Äôm really not sure what to do. I was so excited about singing in a high caliber choir again, but now am feeling really uncomfortable. I feel like my identity is being invalidated. Any advice?

title: How are we supposed to make a living?
body:
Context: I am 31, nonbinary (afab), queer, autistic, and I work in education at a tutoring center. I am both the manager and a teacher there. 



I‚Äôve been in the same job that I thought was a safe place for 5 years now. Two years ago, I realized I was not straight and divorced my husband. Around the same time I started realizing I am also nonbinary. Over the past two years my appearance has also started to reflect that. I have short hair and dress mostly masc. Over the past year especially (although now I‚Äôm starting to think it may have been earlier), I‚Äôve been feeling like my boss has been trying to (slowly) push me out. But she would never directly do it, because she does value me and care about my well being. She has always invited me to spend holidays with her family Bc she has known I have never had a great relationship with mine. But she‚Äôs been more distant lately, for sure. 


Thankfully those first three years I proved myself to be a huge asset to my boss and her fairly new small business. Now that the business is fully on its feet, I am less necessary. There is no where for me to grow in this job, so even if I didn‚Äôt think I was being pushed out, I have still been searching for a better paying job with more opportunities for at least the last two years (not urgently searching, but definitely searching). 


Every interview that I have had over the last two years (around one per month ish) has ended with me feeling like it went great, the other person sounding like they wanted to hire me, and then me not getting the job. My most recent one was in a place where I knew someone who already works there, and after my interview, they told the person I know that they were impressed with my credentials and really liked me a lot. And yet, I didn‚Äôt get that job. 


Today, a coworker told me that they overheard my boss saying that she is worried about the image I give her business. 


So I feel like I‚Äôm not welcome in the only place that‚Äôs been constant for me over the last five years. And I‚Äôm not welcome anywhere else. How am I supposed to make a living and support my family? 


It feels like, at this point, I have to go back in the closet, grow my hair back out, present fem again, and hide my partner just so I can afford to live. 


Idk if I want advice or I‚Äôm just ranting, or maybe both. I‚Äôm just frustrated and very very broke.


Edit to add: I forgot to mention that yesterday my boss recommended me to apply for a different position in a different location that just opened up.

title: Depressed after starting T
body:
I‚Äôm gonna talk to my doctor about this if things don‚Äôt improve/get worse but checking in here first to see what others have experienced. 
I started taking T and am on 2.5 g of gel, 1%. I feel more grounded(?) in my body and really am looking forward to some physical changes and mild voice deepening. Today is my 6th day and the first day I felt calm, but after that I‚Äôve been depressed. Not like I wanna not be alive depressed but like unmotivated, crying spells, etc. Depression isn‚Äôt new to me but I don‚Äôt like feeling like this.  I‚Äôm wondering if maybe my dose is too high? Or I just need to wait it out and let my levels settle? I told my doctor I wanted to go slow and wanted a more androgynous/non-binary transition instead of ftm and this is the dose he prescribed. I‚Äôm trying to wait things out because it hasn‚Äôt even been a week but ugh, it‚Äôs difficult because I don‚Äôt have any people in my life to support me through this. Anyone relate or have any helpful information?

Edit: Thank you everyone for the advice/support. I had a gyno appointment today and luckily the doctor I saw was super trans friendly and let me know I could take half the gel or take it every other day or work out something else with my doc. It was super helpful to learn that this process is gonna look different for everyone and I can work with my doc to sort this out. I‚Äôm gonna reach out to my doc about that and lowering things a bit and I‚Äôm starting therapy next week so hopefully all that‚Äôll help. Gonna leave this post up in case it helps anyone.

title: Previously CIS male dating an AFAB enby seeking advice relating to sexual acts/exploration
body: I'd like to preface this by stating that a lot of this stuff is new to me, so I apologize in advance if I say anything offensive or misuse terms, feel free to discuss any issues in the comments so I can learn more and be better.  Background: I have been a heterosexual CIS male most of my life, but have been accepting/supportive of anyone with non-hetero sexuality or relationships. I tend to be more fem leaning than most men, and am not a fan of toxic masculinity or most men in general (partially due to trauma). A few months ago I began dating an AFAB enby who I have crushed on for a long time, and it has been a bit of a transition for me in thinking and I'm still a bit insecure in my sense of self. They identify as gay and NB, and have also at times said that they are a gay boy (I recently asked for clarification on what that meant to them, and it seems they are more firmly in the middle, with some fem days and some masc days, and they see themselves more so as just gay). Rather than seeing myself as a straight male in a hetero partnership due to the parts involved, I am now seeing myself as being more so pansexual with genital preference (I'm not dating a girl, so to say I am straight would be inaccurate and potentially disrespectful to my partner's identity). I'm still trying to figure myself out in regards to all of this, and I want to do so in a way that is supportive of my partner while maintaining honest/open communication about our thoughts/feelings. I do admit that I have not been the best at communicating this stuff, and it has caused some friction in our relationship as of late. We do seem to agree on most things pertaining to our relationship and where it's headed: We both date to find a life partner, we both want to have/raise children, and we both have similar goals as far as lifestyle and living situations and more. I feel that we have way more in common than the few things we don't quite see eye to eye on so far.  There are two areas that I think are the most important to iron out that I need advice on:  The first thing is that my partner wants to be able to pursue/have relations with women. I am open to exploring this dynamic, but also don't know where my mind will end up on the subject, which I expressed to my partner early on. I'm still trying to see how I feel about this, and with it comes exploring my boundaries and challenging my own preconceptions and my own insecurities/jealousy. My partner had expressed early on that our relationship was the priority, and if I was super uncomfortable with this then they would potentially be ok with not pursuing women. Recently I have tried to express some of my thoughts/feelings relating to discomfort and boundaries, restating that I wasn't sure if this would be something I would be down with long term, which I don't feel was received or understood very well. Now my partner thinks I don't want them to do things with women and has said it's a dealbreaker, even though that wasn't what they said previously and it isn't quite what I said or how I feel. I'm not too sure how to address this or continue to safely explore this space.  The second thing is that, when my partner is feeling more like a masc gay boy, they want to fantasize about being a boy while engaging in acts that satisfy this fantasy. One outlet for this is pegging, either with their partner or with women they are engaged with sexually. I am not into butt stuff, and it makes me a bit uncomfortable. I do think I would be willing to experiment with it when I'm more comfortable with myself, but I'm just not there yet. I'm not sure if it has to do with societal programming or potentially past trauma that I may not be fully aware of, or if it makes me uncomfortable because it challenges my notions relating to sex and sexuality. Recently my partner was in a masc mood, and asked if they could top me and grind on my ass, which I agreed to try. The experience was really uncomfortable for me, both physically (it hurt my spine a bit) and mentally (I saw them as male in this situation). They were a bit aggressive/rambunctious, and were holding me down. They wanted me to fake moans and such to help them get off. I tried to express my discomfort, which was not received well. They felt like I was denying their sexuality and felt like I wasn't willing to do something focused on their pleasure. I'm not into faking things, and I didn't want to continue with a situation that made me uncomfortable. I also don't want them to feel like I don't accept them or that they can't be true to themselves around me. I feel like they aren't being understanding of me and my sexuality/preferences/comfort. I don't know how to address this either.  Tldr; My AFAB enby partner wants to see women on the side, and while I'm down to try it I'm not sure what my comfort level will be long-term. Initially they seemed to place more priority in the relationship, but now it seems like it would be a deal-breaker to them if I were to decide it wasn't for me. My partner also wants to be able to pursue masc fantasies with me and other women physically (like pegging/grinding on me) which I don't think I am comfortable with currently, at least when done to me. They feel like I am not accepting of them and that I'm going back on my word, which I...

title: My partner came out as non-binary and I‚Äôm struggling to accept it.
body: I‚Äôm a cis female married to my partner AMAB for 4 years. When we got married they identified as a male. I grew up in a high demand religion that teaches there are only 2 genders and is quite homophobic and transphobic. 2 years in my partner came out as Bi to me then now another year later non-binary. I felt I tried to adopt their pronouns and tried to picture how this new relationship would work but in my gut feel uncomfortable with it. I feel pretty uncomfortable when they experiment with dresses and makeup and appear more feminine. But I see how happy they are and they‚Äôre a new person in a good way- which makes me really happy for them. But they‚Äôre also a new person. We went to counseling together and counselors said it‚Äôs ok if you‚Äôre straight and the relationship doesn‚Äôt work for you but I‚Äôm having a really hard time accepting that as truth. I‚Äôve been trying for 10 months to shake this feeling of discomfort, don‚Äôt get me wrong, I could have done things a lot better but I felt like I was holding them back and hurting them because I‚Äôve had this thought that a queer relationship doesn‚Äôt work for me, that now we‚Äôve been separated for about 3 weeks. I feel terrible and unsatisfied because I feel like the relationship itself didn‚Äôt necessarily change and was going well.  Now I‚Äôm torn. Is it possible that I can challenge myself and this ‚Äúoff‚Äù feeling, this feeling of discomfort can go away? I love my partner with all my heart but I also feel like everyone around me doesn‚Äôt want me to give myself up for the relationship. Would that be considered giving up my own identity to make it work? I‚Äôm just feeling really heartbroken and stuck.

title: Thinking about top surgery... How do I know if it's right for me?
body: After years of feeling uncomfortable in the gender assigned to me at birth, I came out to my friends and family as nonbinary. I first voiced uncertainty about my gender around the age of five, started to suspect that I was nonbinary around the age of fifteen, and started binding a year ago (after wearing nothing but sports bras since I was fourteen). I'm nineteen now and am looking into options for top surgery but I'm worried that I'll regret it. Even though I have always wanted a flat chest, my mind is racing with all sorts of scenarios (what if I wake up one day and suddenly feel like a woman? What if I get kicked out of a womens' locker room because I can't prove I'm AFAB? What if more feminine clothing looks dumb on me or baggy or something? What if there's a super cute dress or lingerie top...) That will probably never happen. I guess my question is, how do I know if my worries are justified? How do I know if top surgery is right for me?

title: ‚Äúnonbinary skepticism‚Äù is destroying my well-being. [long]
body:
sorry there‚Äôs so much to unpack here. I‚Äôm a bit of a mess at the moment and need somewhere to get it all out. tldr @ end

so, semi-positivity first. I just bought my first actual GC2B binder, with my own money, and I can expect to have it in a minimum of about two days. yay, me! but just like when I got my shitty Amazon binder off a friend of a friend of a friend, I‚Äôm suddenly hit with this overwhelming feeling of ‚Äúoh my god, transitioning is a thing I can do outside of my imagination???‚Äù and it‚Äôs just so much that it‚Äôs making me nervous. but, hopefully it‚Äôll arrive in good condition, and it‚Äôll fit. so I have that to look forward to beyond everything else that‚Äôs dragging me down. üòå

now onto the big bad. I‚Äôm beginning to have a much harder time embracing my nonbinary identity, and presently it‚Äôs not regular flavored transphobes I have to blame for once. if you‚Äôd like me to go into specifics I like the terms transmasc and androgyne but according to the LGBT spaces I‚Äôve encountered more and more of online,  androgyne is ACTUALLY (/s) a ‚Äú‚Äùspecial snowflake term‚Äù‚Äù and it‚Äôs acceptable to shame me for using it ü§® doesn‚Äôt matter that the word‚Äôs been around for ages. apparently I make the community look like a joke by using the word. sure I might not actually be out as androgyne specifically, bUt iM sTiLL a JoKe bcus logic üòå

also, apparently it‚Äôs acceptable to be ‚Äúenby skeptics‚Äù which basically just amounts to someone not believing being nonbinary is possible (because...something about brain structure and how it relates to gender?? who in blue hell actually goes as far as checking brain structure of all things when it comes to gender stuff...anyway.) but still pretending to respect nonbinary people for those sweet, sweet woke points. there are so so many of those people floating around (some of them even go to my school! it‚Äôs so fun! /s) and it‚Äôs honestly got me worried. especially because a lot of them seem to be eighteen or younger and are super quick to dismiss the words and experiences shared by older nonbinary people. maybe they‚Äôll grow out of it, maybe not...but more and more people are speaking out about their ‚Äúnonbinary skepticism‚Äù and it‚Äôs. bad.

does anyone else have experiences in dealing with these sorts of people?? they‚Äôre like regular transphobes but Big Brained and Woke(TM) /s and it‚Äôs getting on my nerves because I don‚Äôt know how to deal. I have a small circle of people who look up to me on Instagram specifically where that crap seems to be the most heavily concentrated and it‚Äôs getting stressful having to stay strong through the onslaught of people bitching to me about how I‚Äôm oh so clearly faking my identity for oppression points. advice on coping is appreciated, or even just sharing experiences w these sorts of people. I‚Äôd like some reassurance that I‚Äôm not alone in dealing with this fuckery in the one place I‚Äôm supposed to feel supported when real life falls through.  I want to be a good role model and an inspiration to fellow LGBTQ people but now I‚Äôm questioning whether or not I should even let myself be visible at all...

tl;dr: enby skeptics r annoying as hell and even with small things to help affirm my gender it‚Äôs getting hard to stay positive at the moment ://

title: I Need Some Advice
body:
I guess I should start by introducing myself. Hi, I go by Cass and I'm 16. I'm a kid, I know, but I also know for certain that I identify as nonbinary.

I was born a female, but I never felt comfortable being that way. I was always considered a tomboy, no one who knows me would tell you otherwise. My dad even thought I might be a trans male. I thought this for some time as well, but I don't feel comfortable with that label either.

I don't feel comfortable identifying as either male or female. They're both equally uncomfortable labels for me. I'm not nonbinary for attention, because all it's gotten me is negative attention. I don't want that, I don't want to be considered special, I just want to breathe.



I just need help. I want to try coming out to my dad. He's pretty accepting, he accepted that I came out as a lesbian and has been really supportive of me. But he doesn't understand a lot of transgender issues. I've tried explaining it to him. He doesn't understand, but is accepting anyways. I don't think know how to explain nonbinary genders to him, and once more I'm afraid of coming out. I want to come out, but it's terrifying.

A lot of people aren't accepting of me. Even people in the LGBT community. I'm just hoping I can find a good community, I just want some stability, really.

title: Feeling really insecure being non-binary at my age (30), and preparing to enter college late in life.
body:
I‚Äôll be the first to say I suck at advocating for my identity. It‚Äôs an insecurity thing that I can‚Äôt seem to shake.

I‚Äôve been out for six years. I love being non-binary. I don‚Äôt really have a specific label for my gender identity. Non-binary lesbian, but in general just ‚Äúqueer, they/them‚Äù

I drown myself in as much non-binary media as I can get. I read gender theory. I‚Äôve spent years doing intense philosophical internal exploration of *why* I identify this way, and why it‚Äôs so important to me. There is probably nothing I understand better about myself than my gender identity.

But, I still present mostly how people expect my AGAB to present. There is nothing wrong with that of course (though I don‚Äôt really want to, again, very insecure, but I‚Äôm slowly challenging it and exploring the alternative fashion I‚Äôm actually interested in). But because of it, I have a really hard time enforcing they/them pronouns. People default to my AGAB pronouns, and I usually tell them initially that it‚Äôs actually they/them. But if they don‚Äôt self enforce, I just deal with the wrong pronouns.

I‚Äôve wanted to expand to they/them/it/it‚Äôs for a few years, but I keep chickening out. Same reason. I‚Äôm really insecure about being older than most non-binary people I‚Äôve met. It‚Äôs been six years, nothing makes me happier than being non-binary, but it‚Äôs like there is this overwhelming imposter syndrome that just won‚Äôt go away.

I think most of my inability to feel valid comes from the sense that I‚Äôll never be truly seen as valid.

I‚Äôm kinda just considering going into the closet while I‚Äôm in school. But that feels like a death sentence to my identity. I feel like I‚Äôm probably going to need to professionally closet after college anyway (I‚Äôm going into architecture) if I want to stand a chance at having a career. I really want to be wrong, but I feel so fucking scared. I feel like the only way to have a normal career is to only be non-binary at home.

I feel so hopeless‚Ä¶ like I‚Äôll never be able to be 100% openly non-binary.

Does anyone have any advice for self advocacy? Any other ‚Äúolder‚Äù non-binary people, or those who went to college late? Anyone who has a Big Job who openly uses they/them, or even neopronouns?

I‚Äôm desperate for any hope that I won‚Äôt have to feel this way forever. I don‚Äôt wanna look back in another six years and have to feel the same way.

title: ‚ÄúAll NB People are Non Dysphoric‚Äù
body:
Every time somebody says I don‚Äôt have dysphoria, I want to scream.
I don‚Äôt WANT dysphoria, but it invalidates my years-long experiences. I can barely leave the house without my chest flat. When someone calls me ‚Äúshe‚Äù I feel like shrinking. When my parents call me their daughter, my family tries to force me to dress ‚Äúlike a girl‚Äù, I want to hide inside myself. I‚Äôve been feeling this for years. It isn‚Äôt because I want to escape female oppression, or because I have body dysmorphia. My therapist agrees- I am dysphoric, however atypical, and so I call myself Trans NB. I want T, I want top surgery, because I‚Äôll finally feel like myself in my body. But I‚Äôm not a man, I‚Äôm nonbinary. I don‚Äôt have a desire to be labeled a man in the world. Not all NB people are the same, and this NB person‚Äôs cried, nearly holed themself up, is preparing to be disowned- all because they can‚Äôt live in a female body, as a female, in the world. I‚Äôm just as trans as you. And I don‚Äôt hate myself for it. I‚Äôve lived with dysphoria for years, and just because you can‚Äôt understand how someone like me can have it doesn‚Äôt make my experiences any less real.

title: Mother controlling my HRT
body:
I've had an incredibly emotionally draining week. 

I'm 23, genderqueer AFAB, been wanting to take T since January after years of being trans and considering HRT in the back of my mind. It was only this year that the constant misgendering as female started affecting my mental health and making me feel worse. I read the forums and health guides for a while, consulted a doctor about it, and got a prescription for T with informed consent. 

My mother flipped out. I'm an adult and should be able to make my own decisions and she knew I was genderqueer but the news I was trying to change my physical self was unbearable to her. I tried to have her talk to my doctor who told her T is relatively safe and they could monitor me for any negative health concerns of which I currently have none. She wasn't reassured and kept panicking and cried whenever I tried to talk to her. 

The last straw was this week, I took my last injection from my first script and tried to make sure I had the refill bottle handy, turns out my mother stole it and the rest of my needles. I'm living with my parents so she had access to my bedroom and she stole my medication because, as she says, she "panicked" and "wanted me to be safe."

The ONLY way I could convince her to give me my meds back without calling the police was to promise I would stop taking testosterone for a few months so we could discuss it more in depth. I understand her apprehension and worry but it's MY decision. My older brother smoked cigarettes for a very long time but she never stole his cigarettes, and she doesn't take weed away from my younger brother. But apparently medicine prescribed by a doctor to try and help my social dysphoria is off the table. 

I'm furious and I have no idea what to do. She gave my meds back because I promised to stop taking them for a while and taking them behind her back would make me as untrustworthy as she is, but I feel disgusting letting her manipulate what I choose to do with my own body. I immediately bought a lock box for my valuables, including the meds, because I don't fucking trust her anymore. But she saw it and feels extremely hurt that I don't trust her and I don't know how to tell her that I'm not going to apologize for hurting her feelings when she is the one who stole my property to try and control my use of prescription medication. 

EDIT: Thank you so much for the kind words and advice. I will try to keep it all in mind. I can't be financially independent from my folks for a while yet but it is good to know that my feelings in this situation aren't unreasonable.

title: I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôll ever be happy being me
body:
Ever since I realised I was nb, I‚Äôve been ridiculed and misunderstood both on and offline. Afterwards I just said I‚Äôm a trans guy, because I‚Äôm afab and leaning to masculine, and then the criticism came from the trans community itself (was part of a fb support group who bashed me for not hating my body parts).
I wanna look more masculine, I‚Äôm constantly seen as a girl and it hurts. I don‚Äôt know where I‚Äôm going with this post, honestly, I just feel alone and sometimes I‚Äôm just not sure if it‚Äôs worth it.   
  
Anyone feel similar? Or just wants to talk? :/

title: Cishet Boyfriend Makes Questionable Remarks
body: TW: Transphobia but no hate speech, body talk/descriptions, body comments, medical transition Hey there everyone, I was wondering if I could get some support from you lovely people about a sensitive topic (I'm using a throwaway alt account for this). I'm nearly 30, polyamorous, intersex, and am a transmasc enby guy who is dating a cishet dude who's not intersex. We'll call him Harold and he's also almost 30. Harold previous to us hooking up last year 100% identified as straight 100%. We only happened because I saw how him and our mutual friend Brian would flirtatiously joke to each other. I made a few quips, quips turned into more and then boom we ended up together. Harold hadn't been with anyone before me, ever, which was part of the reason why Harold and I started hooking up. It was supposed to be a one night stand type of thing but like countless others before us it didn't stay that way. Harold and I have been together for about a year. Early into our relationship Harold tried to keep things comfortable for me and made efforts to become educated about trans issues. Occasionally he would tell me that he was still surprised that he was gay because those thoughts had never crossed his mind before. I understand how being queer can come as a suprise and that it can be a large revelation to have. So I was chill with him saying those things early on, however I thought that things would calm down a bit. Considering as we're coming up to our one year anniversary I'd assume the shock of dating a trans guy would have worn off by now. It hasn't. I still get told I am an "exception", that he's suprised but happy, that I have a hot body, that he likes it when I dress in drag, that I am a bottom because he's obviously the top, that he's still kinda straight, that I will still be hot "no matter what I do", that he's not really gay just gay for me, and that he's worried HRT will change who I am as a person. I mentioned a few months ago that I was getting placed on an HRT waitlist after years of trying to be placed on one. I was really excited and figured Harold would be too but he just got really quiet. Still excited but not his usual bouncy golden retriever self. Then he mentioned that he was worried that HRT was going to change who I was mentally. He then gave me a little like pep talk about how it wasn't going to and that I'd still be me, and I knew the words weren't for me. They were for him. Cause HRT has been a dream of mine since I was 10; almost two decades of dreaming about finally being me fully. I know it's going to change me, I want to be changed. However that day things changed in our dynamic, at least I feel they did. He's brought up HRT and how it's going to change my body during date nights and I can hear this melancholy in his voice whenever he does. When he talks about the body hair growth, my voice deepening, the anatomy changes, I hear a sadness like he's saying goodbye to the parts that will be changed. Everything that brings me joy about the future of my transition feels like they bring him sadness and I don't know how to help him or really what to do. I know what I won't do, I won't stop transitioning medically, I won't stop wanting to be me. I can't. I also know I can't change who Harold is, and I wouldn't want to. He's funny, musical, smart, honest, great with people, and has a supportive outlook on life while also being able to have and deal with difficult conversations. He's a good guy and one of my closest friends. Recently he's started calling himself my "boyfriend" and seems really happy when he does. He wants to do good by me. However recently things have been changing in ways that make me feel overwhelmed. He's been spending more time with a group of his friends who are terminally online gamers. I've met them a few times but don't hangout with them because it's not my vibe or scene and they use language I don't appreciate (not towards me just in general). Last date night Harold brought up "woke culture" and started on a mini rant about it before I cut him off by saying that "woke culture" is my culture as an intersex nonbinary trans dude with dyed hair and that wanting rights and to be treated like a human being isn't a big ask and that it includes trans kids. He quietly conceded and we went about our evening. Then later on he looked at my chest and made a comment about how he is still straight vecause he liked what he saw. I am ashamed to admit I didn't call him out because I was too shocked he said that. That's not the Harold I started seeing a year ago. Even just a week before the woke culture mini rant happened we watched The Birdcage and he kept talking about how he is gay/queer and should have known it sooner. We were having a great time just being dudes who care about each other. Then it's like a switch was flipped during the week and the next date night I was met with "you'll always be hot no matter what you do" and "hmm maybe I am straight" and calling me a bottom just because I don't have the same downstairs bio gear as he does I just don't know what the hell I did or what the hell happened in the 7 days between those date nights but it's like I have mental whiplash from it. One moment he's gay the next he's saying...

title: Baby enby here, how do y‚Äôall know?
body:
Bit of a ramble ahead but the TLDR question is how do you know you‚Äôre nonbinary and not just a cis person gaslighting yourself? I‚Äôm dealing with a lot of imposter syndrome and need some advice. 

So I‚Äôm AFAB but my whole life I‚Äôve felt uncomfortable with womanhood in a way I couldn‚Äôt ever really put my finger on. Ever since middle school it has felt like this costume I put on to make other people happy, and I constantly feel like a ‚Äúphony‚Äù girl. Sometimes the costume can be fun to play around with, but it never feels authentic. I almost get this dissociation with womanhood? Like when someone uses she/her pronouns, or refers to my body‚Äôs ability to get pregnant and perform other ‚Äúwomanly‚Äù functions, it‚Äôs like‚Ä¶I logically know you‚Äôre talking about me, but my brain doesn‚Äôt associate those things with me. In the past couple of years I‚Äôve come to realize I don‚Äôt really feel a connection to womanhood and realized that a lot of the uncomfortable feelings I had for the past decade may have been dysphoria. 

All that being said though‚Ä¶I can‚Äôt shake the inner critic in me that‚Äôs saying I‚Äôm deluding myself and it‚Äôs actually some other issue. What if I‚Äôm just insecure in my femininity? What if I just wanna feel special and different? It‚Äôs worth noting that I grew up in a super conservative and religious household so that probably plays a part in this. 

But I guess my question is, how do y‚Äôall know the feelings you have are nonbinary feelings and not something else? How do you separate gender dysphoria/euphoria from other feelings? I‚Äôm scared to be wrong and contribute to that stereotype that being nonbinary is just a trend for confused people.

title: ‚ÄúRoughhousing‚Äù brings me dysphoria.
body:
I‚Äôve been gradually living a more gender nonconforming life in the last two years. But as I‚Äôve continued to move towards this, I realize just what people‚Äôs perception of me is.

I get jostled around a lot by coworkers (I work in a kitchen, very blue collar) and even my partner likes to roughhouse a lot with me. I‚Äôve honestly *never* been a big fan of roughness, as I find it overstimulating and sometimes frightening.

-but I don‚Äôt know how to set boundaries and ask people not to squeeze the FUCK out of my hand, or smack me in the belly, or grab onto me. I try to not present as some oafish masc person, but that‚Äôs exactly how I‚Äôm treated.

No one would be jostling around a femme person without their consent. Growing up, my dad would mess with me by pinning me down to the bed with his bodyweight where I couldn‚Äôt move. He found it funny, but I‚Äôm tired of being the butt of everyone‚Äôs joke.

Does anyone else have this problem?

title: I'm just scared
body: I was gonna make a different post but I couldn't get myself to even type it. Even getting this one out is hard. I'm only out to 2 people that I know because I'm scared people aren't going to believe me or are gonna just tell me I couldn't be because of how I look(I guess I'm conventionally attractive by some standard, I don't see it,) so of course I couldn't be unhappy with my gender identity. I hate being seen as a cishet man and I don't want to seem that way everywhere I go but I'm just terrified, but since I've started calling myself non binary I've never been happier with anything I've been called. I don't know if all of this is just really circular logic but I'm just scared. Does anyone have any advice or anything? I don't want to just hide forever.

title: How do you know who you are?
body: Hi my name is Giovanni I‚Äôm new to this so forgive me if I get any terminology wrong. I‚Äôm not sure where to begin but I feel lost and I‚Äôm hoping I can find my way with your guidance. I was legally born male but I don‚Äôt feel that title fits who I am. So far in my self discovery I feel I‚Äôm in the middle which I find bothersome because I‚Äôm not feminine or masculine i guess I‚Äôm some what androgynous. For some that might be okay but I feel stress and anxiety because I have to balance two lives. Before I would try and lean to my masculine side and I felt like I wasn‚Äôt true to myself and lately I‚Äôve begun exploring my feminine side wearing makeup and I feel pretty comfortable like this. I feel people generally have had positive vibes about it and it feels amazing because I don‚Äôt feel like I‚Äôm trying to do anything except be myself. I still have masculine features about me but I feel they both make up who I am. What does that make me though? I‚Äôm feminine I like men so am I gay or non binary? It‚Äôs all so confusing and I‚Äôm not 100% where I want to be . It‚Äôs really complex I‚Äôm trying to be as brief as possible help please :/. I‚Äôve thought to myself what my life would be as a woman and part of me feels I‚Äôd be happy. I‚Äôm kinda comfortable having my ‚Äúman bits‚Äù though and I don‚Äôt have major body dysphoria. That could be because I learned to kinda just accept myself because I don‚Äôt have the features I wish I had or the money to fix it. What does that make me? I kinda feel I could be trans but how do you know for sure? Please help, I constantly feel lost and ask my boyfriend ‚Äúhow do you know who you are? Sometimes I don‚Äôt know.

title: Healthcare Question
body:
My company doesn‚Äôt have a nonbinary designation but, for gender (doesn‚Äôt say sex), you can choose not to disclose. However, it‚Äôs caused issues when enrolling for health insurance. I‚Äôve been enrolled for two months and been charged all this time but I recently found out I‚Äôm not actually being covered. HR reached out and told me that the reason I wasn‚Äôt being covered is because the insurance company keeps rejecting my enrolment since it says ‚ÄúDid Not Disclose‚Äù for gender. 

So far, the insurance company has refused to allow my enrolment but is also not refunding me for the last couple months without coverage. And it‚Äôs continuing to deduct from my pay check. They‚Äôre saying I can‚Äôt skip disclosing and I have to pick either male or female. I guess there isn‚Äôt a way to do an exception. Has anyone else experienced this? Do you all just usually go ahead with AGAB?

I know we have to pick our battles but this has been frustrating and causing a bunch of dysphoria. And honestly, embarrassment. I figured my biological sex would only matter to my doctor. A part of me wants to stand my ground but a larger part of me feels I‚Äôm being ridiculous and a crybaby‚Ä¶and that part of me also needs to go to the doctor and get some prescriptions filled.

title: I feel like my partner has different expectations and ideas of what non-binary means than me?
body:
I've been seeing a friend of mine for a few months. It's been going alright, but there is something that keeps irritating me:

On several occasions my partner has by default adressed me in ways you would adress a person who is the binary gender that is not my AGAB. When my partner makes me compliments, the compliments are gendered, again stereotypical compliments for the gender that is not my AGAB. 

Even sex has changed. While we were trying many different things in the beginning and spent a lot of time cuddling, my partner now asks specific acts from me. Those acts require me to take on a rather clear-cut role. I emulate body parts that I currently do not have. That in itself would be fine, but it kind of breaks my heart to see my partner get more pleasure out of that, than out of everything else we did before.

It feels like my partner is imagining me as a gender I am not. I am non-binary. I feel like I have a bit of all genders in me, and none at the same time. To me, non-binary does **not** mean "the mind has binary transitioned, but the body hasn't" or something in that order. Right now it feels like my partner treats me as \[opposite of my AGAB\] in the body of an \[AGAB\].

Last week we had a small disagreement. My partner wanted to cut my hair sometime soon. But I changed my mind about it. Hairdressing is kind of a big deal for me (I'm autistic and have sensory issues with my hair). I've only had another person cut my hair once in the last 11 years. And when my partner said that I needed a more "non-binary" haircut, I didn't feel like it anymore. To me "non-binary" is not a specific look and I don't like the idea that I have to look a certain way to be seen as my gender.

Another potential problem is that my partner's friend group doesn't accept my identity. My partner is binary trans and so is most of the friendgroup. My partner told me that the friends misgender me when I'm out of earshot. And that one of the friends disliked me at first, because I "looked too basic" and they assumed I must be binary trans based on that. Some of them use non-binary as a label for "non-passing" binary trans people.

I like my partner and there are many good things happening between us. But all of this is ringing my alarm bells and starting to stress me out. I tried talking about it, but it was kind of brushed off with a general "But you know I accept you the way you are, right?". I do have a hard time articulating what I need. But it becomes even harder to do that, when there is already an assumption in place that I need to counter.

Can someone here understand this? Am I being too much in my own head? I'd really appreciate any outside perspective, but it already helped writing all of this down.
