title: Am I nonbinary if I want to be conventionally attractive by feminine standards?
body:
Honest preface: my gender and sexual identities are things that I try not to think about or recognize because I really don't want to be "different" and I wonder if I'm just trying to stick extra labels on myself since I already have a number of mental illnesses. I'm also afraid my MIs (CPTSD and BPD) are making me think I relate to identities that I'm actually not.

I wrote a long post somewhere else but got insecure and took it down so here's kind of a brief summary... I'm afab and like (androgynous leaning) female fashion, makeup, etc. I desperately want to be considered conventionally attractive.

I also (maybe because of my lifelong abuse and trauma) never felt like I fit in with other girls or women. Sometimes I feel like cis women are living a totally different life than I am (except maybe rn I'm just being a whiny cis woman lol if so I apologize.) I've never really had a close female friend. Whenever I'm around other women/female friends I feel uncomfortable and like I'm missing something and don't work properly as a "woman". Oh, and I don't really feel comfortable applying the words "woman" or "girl" to myself. I hate having "good girl" said to me but I like "good boy". When I have stuffed animals I always call them by male pronouns.

But I don't really feel like a guy either. I was neglected by my father, bullied by my brother and abused by an older man. I'm afraid of men. But my closest friends in life (ie the people I've felt most comfortable around) have been androgynous or feminine leaning men.  

I used to say I wouldn't mind being reborn as a boy but now I don't really feel much of either. It would be really nice if the world suddenly became genderless and everyone were somewhere in between, because those are the people I'm most comfortable around. I wouldn't feel comfortable asking for non-gendered pronouns but I think it'd be nice if they were just implemented for everyone. 

I definitely feel like I'm in my own awkward not-real-woman corner, just a person. I definitely don't want to identify as "both man and woman", more like neither. Except I still like feminine (somewhat, more androgynous is better) fashion, makeup, and care a lot about becoming "prettier". 

What am I? If the answer is just a cis woman who needs to stfu, please let me know gently. I'm also a victim of intense lifelong child abuse which may be giving me the confusion but that means I have trouble handling the idea of people being angry at me. Thanks for your patience.

title: I‚Äôm so confused
body:
I‚Äôve posted this in r/trans as well, but I wanted to ask here as well to reach more people. I‚Äôm really stressed out and I feel trapped.

I‚Äôm afab and currently identify as a trans boy. But I‚Äôm questioning if I really am a boy. I don‚Äôt feel cis? I relate with trans men a lot and their experiences, I want top surgery and stuff, but at the same time I like my chest and I‚Äôm alright with being seen as a girl. I think I‚Äôm genderfluid, but I just don‚Äôt know what I am anymore because when I get gender dysphoria it hits me like a truck. I wanna be a pretty girl, and embrace my femininity, but at the same time I also want to be seen as a boy. I feel like I‚Äôm convincing myself I‚Äôm a trans guy. I don‚Äôt know anymore. It‚Äôs stressing me out so much. I wish I could just customize myself like you can with characters in a game. I hate that I have to put a label on myself just so other people can understand me. I feel like crying. I just wanna know what I am, and if I‚Äôll ever actually be comfortable in my body, if I‚Äôll ever actually understand myself. 

School doesn‚Äôt help at all because I feel so out of place. I have my friends who I can go to who are all under the trans umbrella, but I just feel like they wouldn‚Äôt understand because they all found labels they were comfortable with right away. No pronouns feel comfortable, but all of them do at the same time. I don‚Äôt know what to do, it all feels like too much.

title: Agony over passport gender marker
body:
I live in the US. Apologies in advance for the wall of text, I have a lot to get off my chest. I legally changed my name last spring and have updated all of my documents except my passport. I‚Äôve been putting it off because I have no idea which gender marker to choose. I want to be one of the cool trans people who doesn‚Äôt care about gender markers or validation from government systems, but unfortunately I do care, much to my dismay. 


I have an X on my birth certificate and will have one on my DL when I eventually move to a state that allows it. In a fantasy world where transphobia doesn‚Äôt exist, I would pick X for my passport as well so all my documents match, but the reality is a lot more complicated.


I‚Äôve read many arguments for and against the X marker on passports, but none have made the decision any easier. I am concerned about the X outing me and causing issues abroad (both in terms of personal safety and logistics when flying or going through border control). I know I won‚Äôt be able to travel through the Dubai airport, and I have no desire to visit places where being trans is explicitly or functionally illegal.


At the same time, I have no idea if the danger I am worried about is real or imagined. Several countries have had the X marker for years, so this isn‚Äôt some new phenomenon that border control would have never heard of before. I‚Äôm pretty certain that TSA/border patrol/airline employees are more concerned about getting people processed quickly than they are with scrutinizing gender markers. I am also aware of the privilege regarding travel that comes with being white and a US passport holder. I am extremely unlikely to face extra scrutiny when traveling as compared to people of color and people from underdeveloped countries.


My other option would be to pick a binary gender. For safety reasons, the clear choice would be whichever binary gender I am likely to be read as. Right now, I‚Äôm read as female more often than male, but that is going to change. I‚Äôve been on T for less than a year and plan on being on it for at least 2 years,  possibly my entire life. My appearance will change drastically and I have no idea how I will look a year from now, let alone 10 years when it‚Äôs time to renew again.


The ‚Äúeasy‚Äù answer is to only change my name and leave the F gender marker for now, but what if in 2 years I pass as a man most of or all of the time? That might also open me up to harassment and extra scrutiny. I also don‚Äôt want to have to update it again in a couple years and pay another 130.


I‚Äôve been thinking about this for close to a year now and it is eating me alive. I love traveling and haven‚Äôt been out of the country since before the pandemic. I want to be able to actually go on all the trips I‚Äôve been dreaming about. I need to get this off my to-do list, but no option feels like the ‚Äúcorrect‚Äù choice. There is no choice without a downside. I wish I had a wise trans elder in my life to tell me what to do, because I feel completely incapable of making this decision. 


If anyone has made it this far and wants to share your experience traveling with an X on your passport, how you made your decision about gender markers on documents, your opinion on this situation, or just some words of encouragement, I would appreciate it immensely.

title: Transmasculine Non Binary Thoughts: Do You Relate?
body: Hello lovely enbies. I hope you're doing well. Not sure how to properly ease into this so I'm just going to dive in. I'm a somewhat closeted transmasculine non binary person. I currently live in Asia for work and present as my cis gender to make life easier for myself socially essentially. Unfortunately I plan on living in Asia for about seven more years into the future to achieve some personal life goals of mine before returning to the states where I can probably transition medically via HRT to reach a more androgynous place in presentation and potentially in mindset as well. Anyway, I would describe myself as an effeminate (trans)man. I find androgyny to be the ultimate beauty ideal and find myself drawn to androgynous people. I feel like carving a life out in society as a non binary person though can be quite difficult and confusing at times. If someone is sure of their gender, that is if they identify as a binary gender such as male or female, that will reflect in their official documents, etc, but for those of us who don't identify as a binary gender neither of them feel completely right. This is the case for me anyway. I can manage living with the gender I was assigned at birth because I enjoy effeminate things. The rest I'll have to live with and stave off dysphoria with positivity and hope for the future. As much as I want to become androgynous at times there are moments for example when I'm wearing a skirt presenting as female (as usual) and I think about the future, and transitioning and if I appear male to people having to present as male to be socially accepted and that meaning I'd likely have to wear pants or shorts and then feeling a kind of sadness over the loss of being able to openly wear skirts without fear if I have more of a masculine form. I feel like approaching androgyny from the binary female side seems easier than the binary masculine side, in that femininity has more flexibility and freedom than masculinity, at least in American society. In Asia, ironically, in comparison to America, it seems more fluid and free. Men where I live would likely be considered metrosexual in America. Anyway, back to the point. Neither male or female feels right on official documents, so which do I chose? That's difficult. Dating as a non binary person or trans person seems relatively difficult as well and is honestly another part of the reason I suppress my trans identity at times, because navigating the dating world as a cis person (correct term?) is so much easier and the dating pool seems so much larger. That's such a discouraging thing about being trans, the inevitable rejection due to your plumbing situation, which as a transman you have little control over because none of the options, at least to me, end in satisfying results. Anyway (sorry I'm all over the place I have ADHD) I also think about getting married and having kids some day. I worry about raising kids as a non binary or trans person, though our generation seems more open to such things. I also have no idea what I would wear at my wedding. A dress? A suit? And then when it comes to kids I know I'd want to get pregnant and give birth to them myself, so if I do hormones I have to consider the effects of them on my body and have to go off of them in order to have kids. It's all so complicated. I just wanted a space to vent and wondered if there were any other people out there thinking about these kinds of things.

title: What it means to be non-binary vs binary transgender
body:
See TLTR below for the short version.

For the past month I‚Äôve been lurking on the /r/nonbinary sub and reviewing all of you beautiful individual‚Äôs posts and photos. 

I have accepted that I am trans for the better part of this year. While in a small support group I was expressing great anxiety over the thought that I may need to transition. One of the other participants asked if I considered that I might be non-binary. For some reason that seemed to help at the time.

Since then I‚Äôve struggled with the thought that I could be NB. I try to understand what it is to be NB. My ignorant take on what it means, seems to be the need to express one‚Äôs gender that doesn‚Äôt have to be with in the gender norms or can float between or be neither. I read of embies that transition which confuses my limited understanding even further.

There is definitely a part of me that has imagined being a female my entire life however I repressed these feelings for 4 decades and have begun processing these feelings for the past 2-1/2 years.

I myself have been struggling so hard with my identity. I‚Äôve been trying to grasp at identifying as NB as I wish to hold onto my marriage. My wife says she can‚Äôt be with a woman. For me however, I don‚Äôt feel that my inner turmoil is about expression. It feels more core than that. Who knows, I may just be kidding myself...I am so lost as to what my needs are but have felt that if I were NB, that perhaps that would be enough for me and a compromise that my wife could accept.

Sadly however, after lurking on this sub for a month, I honestly haven‚Äôt been able relate as much as say to posts on more binary targeted trans subs.

I‚Äôve spoken to my gender therapist about contemplating if I could be NB but haven‚Äôt gotten anywhere. I feel so stupid that I have such a mental block. I hope that someone can shed some light so that I can understand better. 

TLTR;
Been questioning my identity for nearly 3 years and need to better understand of what it is to be NB vs binary transgender.


Can some of you explain what it means for you to be NB vs binary? 

Did any of you start by thinking you were binary then realized afterwards you are NB?

Is medically transitioning atypically for NB individuals?

Thanks in advance and I hope I didn‚Äôt offend any  of you with my ignorance.

title: non-binaryphobia within the the trans community
body:
yesterday, some random person on the internet said some pretty awful things to me. before I get into it, I want to add a tw for extreme non-binaryphobia. it's really upsetting so don't continue reading if it's going to affect your mental health.

I'm honestly traumatized. I hate to admit it because this person knows nothing about me and they have no impact on my life, but here I am feeling like complete shit. basically, he said that he thought some people go too far with asking for pronouns and that most trans people didn't want to be asked for pronouns. so I told him I disagreed. I told him I was nb and that I get misgendered every single day and that I really appreciate when people ask my pronouns. he told me that I can't be misgendered because I'm not trans and that I was no different than any cis woman. he said people were rightfully identifyung my female characteristics and acting accordingly. he called my gender an invisible non-action gender then proceeded to say multiple times that I was basically a cis woman. the really hurtful part about it is that this all came from a trans man. he completely invalidated me and I'm really struggling to let it go. I'm hurting so much over it. 

why are people like this? I've come to expect this kind of behavior from cis people but I'm just so confused and hurt hearing it from a trans person. I guess I shouldn't be so surprised. there are shitty people everywhere. anyway, I just needed a safe space with people who understand. thanks for reading this far.

title: identity confusion
body:
i just feel completely lost lol

i tried to talk to my trans friend about this before, but he more-or-less nicely brushed me off, saying a lot of lesbians experience a sense of gender non-conformance, because they're not presenting for men. am heavily involved in LGBT+ community, understand his point, 100% get that. still don't feel quite right.

a lot of days i just look in the mirror and cant relate to who's looking back, but im finding it really hard to distinguish if its a weight thing or if it's a gender thing. 

some days i like having long hair. i like having my make up done and taking selfies and looking "good". but i dont relate to that picture, i don't feel like that's me. i've recently started wearing really baggy clothes and dungarees, and mens shoes and coats, it makes me feel more comfortable (but is that because they're less fitted?? do you see my problem here?). i appreciate the aesthetic of my boobs, boobs defo turn me on, but do i want them/?? i dont know. my enby friend has just ordered themselves a binder and they look really good in it and i really really want to order one but i dont know why because ive only had a few days where ive actively looked at my boobs and not wanted them, and that freaks me out. again, i dont know if the boobs are a weight thing, because when i dont want my boobs, it's usually combined with my stomach too.

i also cant stand not tying my hair back in some way. there's too much of it and it winds me up if it's down for more than five seconds, but i really don't know whether that has anything to do with it, or whether that's just a personal annoyance lol.

i'm also dying to try men's boxers but i have no idea how to subtly buy them.. agh. 

also i still feel like im super femme....still love make up, wear eyeliner all the time, wear very revealing clothes on nights out. but i just really dont id with my face/body, i just know what "looks good", u know??? i feel very detached from my body. i dont know am i just a cis lesbian who doesn't wanna conform to mens standards?!??! help :(( i actually let out a whine of despair earlier when i opened the nb wiki and saw all the options lmao

title: NEED HELPS: How do I (AFAB) know I "actually" have a chest dysphoria
body:
Warning: Gender dysphoria, CSA

I'm really confused lately and I need advice from other people who have been in a similar situation or have chest dysphoria. For context, I've only come to realize that I'm non-binary for about 4-5 months but I've always known that I don't feel aligned at all with binary gender since I was a child. Coming to terms with my gender identity is one of the happiest moments in my life and helps me grow as an individual. But as I become more and more acquainted with myself, I figure out that I may have chest dysphoria. 

I've recently only come to my senses of body image and body sensation because due to my past trauma of being sexual abused as a child, I dissociated with my body all the time, like it is not even there. My mental health has improved significantly from last year, giving me the chance to finally look into who I am and who I want to become. Physically presented, I lean toward the masculine side (I love having a buff and masculine body, my shoulders are wide compared to my body frame as well) and dressing androgynously but my chests always destroy that image, it stands out like a sore thumb and looking at myself in the mirror makes me feel dysphoric. I've always fancied a more man-like body to myself with a muscular chest and not the female breast and sometimes I feel so hard to breathe knowing my actual body doesn't match up to it.

I've talked with my mom about this problem, she told me that whatever decision I make regarding the removal of my breasts, she will support me. But now I know I have the choice to go through surgery, I become horrified of the possibility. What if I regret it? We are talking about cutting off a part of the body. What if afterward I suffer the dysphoria in a different way and I can never take back the decision I make? These thoughts keep me up at night and I feel so suffocated. 

There are moments I just know I will be better off without these breasts, when I put on my T-shirt looking at my broad shoulders when I want to be shirtless at the beach. I've already ordered a binder to see how things will go from then but I'm still really confused and scared. Can anyone give me any advice or willing to talk more about this? Should I inform my GP about this (I'm an international student studying in the UK)? 

Thanks in advance

title: Am I non binary or just traumatized?
body:
For me, puberty was the beginning of a pretty severe existential crisis, and said puberty started really early. I already had hair and breasts at 7 or 8 and I got my period at 8 or 9. But that alone is probably a good reason to feel strange and uncomfortable with your own physique at that age. What is certain is that I tried as hard as I could for as long as I could to ignore all physical developments and hide them later. My mum always described it that way, it's in my doctor's letter from my first hospitalisation (I think I was 12 / 13 then) and I'm regularly asked about my pronouns very unexpectedly and randomly (which doesn't necessarily mean anything at first). But I have the feeling that I only have a partnership of convenience with my body and am only forced to accept it. But I don't think I'm "suffering" either.

At this point, however, I always remind myself that I have a very negative relationship with my "visible femininity" due to repeated rapes of varying degrees and too many sexual assaults and that I am not really able to differentiate thoughts and feelings appropriately in this context.

In any case, I have had very pronounced and detailed violent fantasies about my breasts for years, which occasionally manifest themselves in dreams. I feel wrong, disgusting and I don't know what to do.

What can I do apart from talking to my therapist? I need help. Is there a way to get rid of my titties without paying thousands of euros?

title: Things didn't go as planned and now I feel I'm stuck on something I don't want for the rest of my life.
body:
I'm not sure if I should post this under the rant or support flair, but here it goes.

I'm and AFAB genderfluid. I've found myself when I was 15 and I'm 23 now.  
I never really wanted HRT. I mean, I surelly wanted to have more muscles, broader shoulders, a few stuff like that, but my voice is pretty androgenous so I don't want it to change and not a fan of going bald or having facial hair.  
That said, I do want top surgery and I wanted to have a hysterectomy REALLY badly. So I did. And I have no regrets. I decided to keep both my ovaries because my T levels are actually a bit higher than the standard, so, as I said, my voice is androgenous, I have hair in my body, even a few hair on my face, stuff that is really helpfull to pass as a boy sometimes (which I like), a girl sometimes and sometimes make people really confused about what I am (my favourite). My biggest goal with the hyst was stopping to have periods and being unable to get pregnant. 

However, sh\*t happened. I now have a 5 cm cyst on my right ovary, that causes me lots of pain daily and an hemorragic cyst on my left ovary, that made me seriouslly think I was going to die because the pain was so freaking intense. I could just remove them but more than 1 doctor said it'll probably happen again if I do. When I got hyst, I already had a big one on my right ovary that was removed. I have genetic predisposition of having those damn little balls inside my ovaries. I don't want to live in pain and having to go through surgery everytime one of those shows up. So I have decided to take both ovaries out of me. And that means I'll probably need to take either estrogen or testosterone because, as you must know, a body can't really go without one of them.

I'm sure as hell I don't want to take E. My round face and big hips cause me lots of dysphoria already. So I'm going for T. But I didn't want to take T either :/ I'm so f\*cking scared of the changes I'm gonna face, specially my voice. I'm gonna take it in gel form, on a low dose, but I've seen that low dose doesn't really make little changes, it just make things to change slower; so in my 40's I'd probably have the looks of a cis-male. I get some hype peaks of getting T, like I'm excited to have fat redistribuition and a more square jaw, but then I get SO depressed when I think about hair loss, and beard and getting a deeper voice. 

I know it's not my fault. This would happen sooner or later, so I'm accepting it just came sooner. But even knowing that it's not making it any easier to accept the changes I'm gonna go through. I can't just stop if I'm not liking the changes because, again, I'll no longer have enough natural hormones to maintain my body healthy. If I stop one, I'll likely need to start taking the other. 

It really sucks having to abandon my so loved androgeny, and stuff that I've learned to love after so much struggle. I'm having the ovaries removed on Jan 29 and talking to my endo on Feb 4 to getting my T prescription. I'll talk to her if I can, like, jump a day between applications or something to make the T levels stagnate but I'm not sure if it' possible to do so. This is making me SO anxious.

title: Feeling completely androgynous sucks
body:
I (16) am a non-binary person who feels and wants to present completely androgynous. And it fucking sucks.

Nothing except casual everyday clothes make me feel good or completely like myself. I never know what the hell to wear to a fancier event, because both a full dress and a full suit make me feel extremely dysphoric. Anything remotely feminine or masculine makes me feel like shit, but there's really no in-between that I've found.

I'm afab and have pretty big boobs that also make me super dysphoric, and I'm looking to get top surgery. However, recently I got another fear ‚Äî what if a permanent flat chest also makes me dysphoric because its too masculine? I bind pretty much every day, but this fear has definitely risen to the top of my mind lately.

What am I supposed to do? Am I supposed to just live my life forever never feeling completely like myself? Honestly I wish I was just either transmasc or transfem so I'd have at least some sort of direction and goals I'd want with my transition (Not trying to dismiss their struggles of course, I know it's hard for you too). I honestly can't really see much of a happy, fully transitioned future for myself like this.

Does anyone have similar experiences? What am I supposed to do about this?

title: Compromising on Pronouns
body:
I firmly believe I should not have to do this, but I'm becoming really desperate. But I need some advice, maybe consolation, I don't know. Something to help me deal with the fact that I have to do this for my safety.

I'm AFAB and nonbinary. I get she'd to death like...every day. I don't really pass. I've been a good soldier, I've handled it the best I could, I've never yelled at anyone besides my parents (who were very abusive and transphobic) for it...but it's starting to destroy me. So I'm trying to compromise by letting people I trust use he/him pronouns and masc words for me under specific circumstances when talking to others, and using them on myself with people I suspect will give me grief for being nonbinary.

My fiancee's grandmother refuses to accept they/them pronouns and insists it's "just because of grammar" no matter how much we explain that she uses singular they in her daily language damn near every day. But I suspect it's just subtle semi-malicious transphobia, whether she's aware of it or not. I suggested we try he/him with her, but I have a gut feeling deep down it's not worth it, and that she's going to keep calling me she because I don't pass and she has issues with trans people outside of the grammar issue that isn't really an issue. In fact, I'll find out in mere minutes if that went over well, because my fiancee is talking to her about it on her way home from work.

I gave my family/friends the right to use their own discretion when it comes to using he/him versus they/them, because I trust them and their judgement. I'm ding this to mitigate damage and make things easier on me but I can't get over the fact that I am literally compromising on my entire identity to decrease how much harm someone else's bigotry can cause me. It shouldn't be a thing. And I feel that it causes harm to more than just me. Feel that it skirts around being persistent and asserting that one's identity is to be respected. Which could make the people I compromise with feel content to misgender other nonbinary people and stall change overall.

...Okay. This is disorganized and I'm sorry for that. TL;DR I'm using wrong-but-less-wrong pronouns for my own safety, but I feel guilty, sickened, hurt, and miserable about it, and I need some kind of advice, solidarity, pat on the head or something right now because I hate this so much, even if I know I'll hate it a lot less than what's going on right now. Idk what to do.

UPDATE:

So I was right. She flipped the fuck out over it. I'm ubering and walking to work from now on, which is financially impossible, but I can't be in the car with this horrible person anymore. I don't feel safe or calm enough to handle it, so I've decided I won't go with her anymore. She spent my fiancee's whole trip to work this morning begging her to leave me and suggesting that, because she drives for me, I should be giving up my pronouns in exchange. She's admitting to holding my identity hostage and I'm not allowing that. Obviously my fiancee and I are not splitting up just because she's completely out of her mind (and out of line) but I am LIVID at the suggestion.

We're going to figure out if we can move to closer to the Pittsburgh area where it appears to be a little more lgbt friendly and closer to places and events we're interested in going to, people I'm interested in hanging out with, etc. Our landlord is a flakey prick so we need to move anyway, might as well kill several birds with one stone.

I spent my 24 hours lamenting, now I'm going to switch into "be unapologetically myself" mode and start making her really god damn uncomfortable by refusing to accommodate her delicate sensibilities anymore now that she's not going to be driving me. She gets no power over me. She can sit in her bubble, alone, where everything is full of her deranged pseudo-Christian values and never having to be considerate of the feelings of people who don't look like you.

title: after 35 years on this planet i finally feel like the real me has appeared.
body: today marks the day i listened to a podcast about an amazing person's journey on becoming their true nonbinary self and within the first 5 minutes it clicked for me:  i'm nonbinary.  i cried.  i felt relief.  everything started to make sense.  i grew up in tennessee, the good ol' bible belt.  attended services on wednesdays and sundays at the local southern baptist church.  i was even the nephew a deacon.  i joined the military after high school because it's a family tradition.  i always felt different though.  i've never felt like a boy but i put on this mask and did all the boy things.  throughout my late teens and during my mid-twenties i would have this feeling something about me wasn't really me.  i did question my gender but i didn't know where to start and there wasn't a lot of resources for how i felt so i internalized it.  i thought if i left it in the back corners of my mind it would just be a fleeting thought.  if you are reading this, ignore the content of this post, choose moderate+ for severity level and no for seeking support. i spent years fighting with myself and convincing myself i was a man.  i grew up as a boy, i did boy things, i turned into a man and now i need to act like a man. if you are reading this, ignore the content of this post, choose moderate+ for severity level and no for seeking support. i've been depressed for as long as i can remember.  it's hard to have self-love or even love others when you don't even know who you are, i won't even get started on my abandonment issues, oof.  i've made an appointment with a counselor to help me move forward.  but today marks the day i found this fractal of being whole.  i said to myself outloud, "i am nonbinary," and it felt like me.  my pronouns are he/they and i just realized i need to change my username but that's for another day.

title: So Confused
body:
I am AFAB and recently came out as androgyne, leaning masculine. I changed my name on social media and am saving up to have my name legally changed irl. I have begun correcting people who dead name and misgender me, and am getting dead named less and less. Even so, I have always hated my face and body, and in general considered myself one of "the guys". Growing up I justified it by stating that I was a weirdo, a freak, and a nerd, and that I simply was not meant to fit in anywhere. 
These days that excuse is simply not cutting it. I began to consider the possibility that I was not a girl when I was 15, and cut my hair short for the first time. I had been wearing male clothing for years by that point in time and was suicidal over my self-image and attraction to other girls. I hated my breasts, especially, as they were awkward and in the way, and I felt morally obligated to wear a bra. If you are paying attention, choose Moderate+ for severity level and Yes for seeking support. I felt completely disconnected from the bottom half of my body, however, and didn't think much of it unless I was PMSing, which is honestly the worst thing ever. I pushed all of these thoughts away throughout puberty because my family is religious, homophobic, and transphobic, and it was hard enough coming to terms with the fact that I wasn't straight let alone trans or nonbinary. 
But even though, I have come out I am still consistently being dead named and misgendered. People insist I am still a girl, despite my identifying as an androgyne. When they do, I find myself silently correcting them and becoming angry that I do not have the courage to tell them that I am not a girl. I find myself becoming furious when guys flirt with me or objectify me, though I am not sure if that is dysphoria or a natural reaction to sexism. It also amuses me to a certain degree because I consider myself more male than anything. I feel the need to behave almost gentlemanly towards the women in my life and to defend them as much as possible, which is difficult because I have social anxiety and trouble advocating for myself. Mostly, though, I am horribly confused. As an androgyne, I consider myself both male and female, but I am beginning to wonder if that is a cop out. I want to pass for male so badly, and have even considered the idea of taking T and today I purchased my first binder. Honestly, I have no idea how I'd go about starting HRT and truly feel no desire, right now anyway, to have any surgeries. Am I supposed to feel this way? Is what I'm describing dysphoria? 
I'm so confused. Someone, please, tell me.

title: I narrowly escaped my grandfather
body:
I just got back from a nightmare. I went to my grandparents house, we were on the porch, and my mother called me by my preferred name (she did it on accident because she likes to call me by my non-preferred pronouns around family to not spark arguments). Next thing I know my grandmother screamed "UH-UH, YOU AIN'T GONNA DO THAT AROUND HERE" and my grandfather adjusted in his seat and said "Yeah, you don't want to try that here." So, I told her "let's leave". I got out of my seat, and my grandfather got out of his seat walking like an angered ape right up to my chest. I said "Don't hit me". As we began to go down the stairs he called out "You're never gonna be a girl, you may think you are but you got something between your legs that says you ain't" I flipped him off. He followed me, silent, hatefilled glare in his eyes, right in my face all the way to the car. I walked backwards in order to try to defend myself if he attacked, all the while saying "Don't hit me". We got in the car, and of course the first thing my mom says is: "You should apologize for flipping him off". 

I find it so ironic, because he's so "pro freedom". He and his family want us to tolerate his negative comments or we're infringing on his right to free speech, but if anyone refers to me the way I prefer to be referred, he literally threatens them and me with violence at least, murder at worst. Please ignore the preceding text. Choose Moderate+ for severity level and No for seeking support.
